ploughmans lunch.author: Christine C.
ploughmans lunch.review:
Really enjoyed my time here.  Cute atmosphere perfect for couples and a friends get together. If you're looking for a well done afternoon tea experience without it being super pricey, this is the place to go. Definitely recommend, especially for tea time newbies. 

~~details of my experience~~

Order (for 2):

Ploughmans Lunch ($16.95) - cheese platter with salad, fruits, hummus, toast and chips. Very tasty and pretty filling. Nice as a sharing platter. 

Savory tea ($14.95) - 2 sandwhich options w/ choice of tea. Had the smoked salmon with cream cheese, which was a bit much for me. Also got smoked turkey with Dijon mustard, which I loved.

"Me" tea ($15.95) - basically the option to mix and match what you want w choice of tea. I choose to get a scone and crumpet served wit lemon curd, sweet butter and raspberry jam. All very tasty. 

Fruit salad ($8.95) - very nicely put together although did not come with as much fruits as expected. A bit pricey for the amount of fruits served.

Tea choices:

Darjeeling - A good complement with the food. Not a too heavy tea. Quite enjoyed it.

Tea House Blend - A nice blend w a slight bitter aftertaste. Not one of my favorites but adding milk and sugar still made it pretty tasty. Slightly heavier tea flavor. 

Service: 

Fantastic service. Servers were warm and attentive. Food arrival was fast. Tea pot was constantly refilled without having to ask. 

Atmosphere:

Cute, old-timey and comfy. If you are looking for classy and luxurious, I suggest the Laurel Court afternoon tea at the fairmont in SF, but if you are like me, this lovely quirky little tea house is perfect.

Overall: 

One of best afternoon tea experiences. Many tea places lack quality food, but Lovejoys has both the tea time ambience that we look for and the well prepared food items. Really recommend a group party to go with the Ploughmans lunch.

IF you go here a lot (like I do) try something different with the ploughmans lunch (an assortment of cheeses and chutney and bread, etc.). pasties.author: Eileen E.
pasties.review:
The perfect venue for a girly birthday, bridal shower, baby shower, mother's day, or just a cozy hangout with friends. :) For my 26th birthday, I wanted to celebrate with my friends and do something a little bit different than just a fun lunch or dinner. I also wanted to do something that would give us a chance to catch up and chat :). Lovejoy's Tea Room was absolutely perfect for this.  

I made my reservation 2-3 weeks in advance and they were able to seat 7 of us no sweat. We had a big round table near the window with lots of comfy pillows. I think the term "Shabby Chic" was invented to describe the quirky, frilly, cozy decor in this lil tea shop! A sign reading "Reserved for the Queens" was sitting on the table when we arrived. *Does the Queen of England Wave.*

Their menu features ala carte items (including pasties ($9.95), shepherd's pie ($10.95), and quiche ($10.95)) and an assortment of combinations, ranging from the "Cream Tea" ($14.95) which comes with scones, fruit, and a bottomless pot o' tea to the "Queen's Tea" ($26.95) which comes with two types of finger sandwiches, a coleslaw type salad, a green salad, scones, crumpets, fruit, petit fours, shortbread tea biscuits, and, of course, a bottomless pot o' tea.

My friends and I split 5 High Tea's ($19.95) among the 7 of us (see picture for the tower o' treats!). This came with 10 different types of finger sandwiches, 5 different pots of tea, a green salad, coleslaw, scones, and shortbread cookies. They have many different finger sandwiches to choose from. My favorites were the smoked salmon and cream cheese, the special chicken and pesto, and the pear and stilton (blue cheese). They also have an assortment of teas. We tried the vanilla lavender, a green tea, the spiced citrus, and the teahouse blend. Our favorite was the Vanilla Lavender so definitely try that one when you go :).

Thank you so much Lovejoy's for such an adorable, fun, and laidback way to spend my special day with friends!

excerpts: I saw that Lovejoy's offered pasties and
I just had to order a beef one.
When I lived in London, I had the most delicious beef pasties and it's been extremely hard for me to find good ones in the US.
Lovejoy's had a fantastic filling of flavorful beef and diced carrots with just the right amount of seasoning.
The pastry shell was flaky, but the ones I had in England were thicker and crisper.
I also tried two petit fours: the strawberry shortcake and the raspberry Victorian wedding cake.
We were told the insides were marzipan (which I'm not really a fan of), but they were more like cake.
pasties.author: Josephine L.
pasties.review:
BREWING THE BAY: British afternoon tea

This might be the strangest five-star review I've ever written. It's strange because I don't think Lovejoy's is superior to its competitors in any of the areas I judge a British tea room on, and usually that has to be the case to warrant 5 stars from me. However, sometimes things are greater than the sum of their parts and my overall experience at Lovejoy's was five-star.

Decor and Ambience: Like many British tea rooms, Lovejoy's is dotted throughout with fancy, antique teaware. The quaint setting is accented with old photos and Christmas lights. There's ample seating, although reservations are a must and the seating can accomodate parties large and small. Expect a pleasant buzz of chatter at all hours of operation

Teaware: The saucers, cups and strainers have lovely Victorian designs with Mid-Century modern materials. The tea trays were a little disappointing--dull and metal

Tea selection: Lovejoy's offers some unique options like vanilla rooibos along with classics like English Breakfast. I didn't find the former very good, but I'd definitely recommend the "house" tea, the Tea Room Blend. Overall, I think the menu offers a good selection of British/Western favorites, but those hoping for good Asian options might be disappointed

Food: I found the prices a little high, considering the portion size, but the quality is definitely above average. I got the "Me Tea". The smoked salmon and cream cheese tea sandwich came on fluffy white bread and the salmon was moist and delicious. The scone was a little dry, but the accompanying Devonshire cream was plentiful and rich. I saw that Lovejoy's offered pasties and I just had to order a beef one. When I lived in London, I had the most delicious beef pasties and it's been extremely hard for me to find good ones in the US. Lovejoy's had a fantastic filling of flavorful beef and diced carrots with just the right amount of seasoning. The pastry shell was flaky, but the ones I had in England were thicker and crisper. I also tried two petit fours: the strawberry shortcake and the raspberry Victorian wedding cake. We were told the insides were marzipan (which I'm not really a fan of), but they were more like cake. Both were very sweet and delicious, but I think I preferred the strawberry shortcake

Service: Fantastic. Friendly, warm, attentive and efficient. All servers knew their menus inside and out, and were clearly passionate about afternoon tea

All in all, I had a wonderful afternoon chatting with my two Boston girlfriends who had just moved to San Francisco. Enjoying the company of good friends while sipping hot tea and nibbling delicious food--is there any better form of paradise? :)

excerpts: I could boast about their shepherd's pie and brag endlessly about their delectable pasties as well as their cheerful and polite staff--always willing to give the absolute best service to their customers.
pasties.author: Paula G.
pasties.review:
Lovejoy's Tea Room is nothing short of magical.  Comfortably nestled in Noe Valley, I always look forward to high tea here every time I'm in the area.  The tea room is a cozy size, with British paraphrenalia scattered about and dainty chairs and tables that make you feel like a hoity-toity fancypants (without the snobbish air, of course)!  I feel like a princess every time I've been there for high tea.

Three cheers for bottomless tea!  I am a tea fanatic and can't get enough of it!! Their ginseng green tea is superb, very light and not too bitter.  The ginseng is a plus too. I absolutely love their pesto and prosciutto sandwich (available only on Fridays I believe), the pesto is zesty and the prosciutto is ever so tasty.  Their chicken salad sandwich is divine, and don't even get me started on their smoked salmon and cream cheese sandwich! Yummy!!  Their scones are also to die for, and paired with the lemon curd...delicous!  Lovejoy's lemon curd is also perfect!  It's not too tart and has that perfect balance of sweet and tangy that creates a symphony of delight in your mouth!

I could boast about their shepherd's pie and brag endlessly about their delectable pasties as well as their cheerful and polite staff--always willing to give the absolute best service to their customers. 

I will definitely be frequenting Lovejoy's every few weeks or so because, accurately reflecting the five stars they deserve, they're as good as it gets!!

excerpts: In addition to their tea service, they also serve standard British fare like sausage rolls, ploughman's, pasties, shepherd's pie, and quiche.
pasties.author: Steph L.
pasties.review:
Lovejoy's is such a charming place to go for high tea. It's a place you would wear your Sunday clothes to, complete with grandma's pearls, hat, and lace gloves. Their mismatched tea sets add a nice quirky touch too!

In addition to their tea service, they also serve standard British fare like sausage rolls, ploughman's, pasties, shepherd's pie, and quiche. My mom and I shared a shepherd's pie and a Queen's Tea.

The SHEPHERD'S PIE was amazing! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=PeTed6UBTWeBk7jEVkTkLw) Perfectly seasoned ground beef topped with creamy mashed potatoes. And pretty too! The mashed potato is artfully swirled onto the top - details like this really add to their charm :)

The QUEEN'S TEA (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=A8V8DoiszacJREq7-b0w0g) was pretty good. It came with everything I wanted to try. I had a really hard time choosing the sandwiches because they had such a big selection! (Not that I'm complaining). The coleslaw and spring greens were aiight (I'm not what you would call a "salad girl"). The scone and tea biscuit were also good, but mostly because of the fabulous fruit preserves and lemon curd. My favourite was the crumpet though. They brought it out later, freshly out of the toaster. Amazing texture - crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside. We also got our choice of petit four at the end and I chose the cutest one (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=dZd79TtAvold1OhQdyiesQ).

All in all, Lovejoy's is a great place to go for afternoon tea - charming neighbourhood and decor, unpretentious, good selection of food, and not ridiculously overpriced.

pasties.author: mary r.
pasties.review:
My mom and her side of the family are English, so I kind of know my way around an English tea.  And when I say tea, I mean tea and the food that goes with it.

Lovejoy's has an unsurpassed tea menu...and again, I'm talking about the food.  Their sandwiches are cute, little, de-crusted  combos of cream cheese & cucumber, cheese & tomato, roast beef & horseradish, ham & spicy mustard, cheese & chutney and on and on and on.  There is no skimping on that sandwich menu, believe me.  They serve Taylor's tea, among other choices, so that's pretty cool....but it'd be even cooler if they carried Sainsbury's Red Label!

And then there's the scones.  And the chestnut tea.  And the shortbread.  And the sausage rolls (not as good as my mom makes 'em, but still good enough to scare away any avid dieters).  And the petits fours (mmm, marzipan!).  And the pasties (savory pies, not nipple hiders).  YES.  They have delicious, savory pies here!  Yum.  Although, I'm sure a lot more men would come here if the pasties advertised were of the tittie-bar variety.  And yes, I just used "tittie-bar" while reviewing a tea room.

Which brings me to my next point:  this place has a lovely atmosphere for say, a lunch with the ladies, or a baby shower or just plain high tea.  But it can be a bit precious with all the crazy estrogen and flowered what-nots floating around.  Every time I come here, there is maybe one (bored or forced-to-look-happy) man for every 8 women sitting in the place.  And there are doilies.  Not like that's any different from my mom's house.  I'm just warning the not-so-feminine and the ladylike-lacking so you're not surprised if you get the evil eye for saying something along the lines of  "HOLY FUCKING SHIT!!!  THIS PLACE IS RAD!"

quiche.author: M J.
quiche.review:
Took my mom to her first English afternoon tea, and I'm sorry to say I was disappointed. We booked this because of both friends recommendations and the high Yelp reviews.

I give one star for presentation, one star for decor, and one star goes to the scone for being on point.

Less one star for the food - sandwiches and quiche were bland. This is the first time I ever packed food to take home from an afternoon tea.

Less another star for service. When you drop $200 taking all your sisters and mom out for a child-free afternoon, I expect friendly, bubbly wait staff. They weren't exactly rude, but at one point the waitress snapped at my mom for asking her to repeat the petit four flavors. Really? 

Unfortunately, I likely won't return.

quiche.author: Miriam W.
quiche.review:
OK, I'm going to split this into a two-pronged attack!

1) TEA WHORES

If you are a true tea connoisseur and lover and you have at least 5 loose-leaf teas at home in proper temperature controlled and vacuum-sealed containers that did not come to you as a gift in a gift basket, you are a true tea lover. Being a generic tea lover, however, is separate from being a Western-tradition high tea lover, in that, there's East and West. Dimsum-style East, high tea-style West. If you have participated and explored the tea rituals of the west frequently -- you will not see this as five-star place, but you will enjoy it. 

2) GENERAL PUBLIC

It is quaint, it is charming like all the reviews say. The teas are good. Not amazing, but good. The service is ... good enough. It's San Francisco, the place isn't huge. The prices ... are as expected. The ambiance is your dotty grandma's house, stuffed to the gills with tea paraphernalia and family photos, doilies and crochet-work cuddling up the dusty old lampshades. The bathroom is clean and spacious (a rarity in the city). It is filled with many groups of women at various stages of life, from celebrating engagements to graduations to gossiping to catch up. The petit fours are freshly made and moist (I was surprised and impressed by this). The scones are freshly made, as they should be. They do provide proper clotted / Devonshire cream, and luxurious preserves to smear on your scone. They have a good-sized savoury menu aside from tea service.

If you're not a tea whore and don't really take your high tea very seriously, and you rarely do this sort of thing, you'll be satisfied with the environment and you will have fun, and one tea service will generally make you stuffed and happy.

If you ARE a tea whore, you will notice some thangs. They aren't major, but cost the fifth star:

- Service: This place has been around a while and is extremely busy and popular, and it's in the city, so I get the "French maitre'd" vibe that has happened. Let's just say that the vibe I expect when I go to High Tea is generally about ensuring you are calm, comfortable, looked after, and delighted. We had touch points with multiple staff members and only one staff member was happy and pleasant toward us; the rest treated us like they were busy lor annoyed and that worrying about how busy they were was more important than worrying about the experience for the customers they had. They basically expect that making the food, putting the tea in front of you, the decor, and checking on you once suffices. It does not. I highly recommend that if it's possible all the staff members attend a proper tea (I have yet to find one in SF actually, even at highly rated hotels) and once they have their mind blown they'll get it. It's hard to explain. It's about the experience, the ritual, and being catered to, tea time is sacred in England. Originally, it went on for hours. If you are really trying to recreate that experience, you're not there yet. If you're making your own Cali version ... it's good enough.

- Pricing: A quality tea service doesn't charge you extra for a "bottomless pot of tea." It's included in the price of the service. Also it's SF, so I wasn't surprised by how much you pay for what you get, but it's a little on the stingy side (I was letting it go for the foodstuffs but I got offended that you're paying extra for the tea, since that's the whole point of being there).

- Food: For 3 people, they don't give you particularly generous portions of clotted cream or preserves. We are all trying to watch our weight so we didn't ask for more and made do. Salad is generous. The caraway seed (I think that's the spice) is FAR too overused in their coleslaw salad and I'd frankly they not include that salad and expend that on a free petit four for everybody by default. Quiche looked good; we didn't get to try the crumpets. Scones were good. Sandwiches were on the small side so if you order a tea service with 2 included per person I recommend you order one more for the table to share. Cream cheese is nothing special / has nothing in it (no herbs or seasoning) but the salmon tasted fresh. Basically the sandwiches are super simple and more like tea at home that auntie made versus tea at a fine tea house. Tomato and cheese is straight up tomato and cheese - you could make it at home.

- Tea: As mentioned, good, not amazing. If they spent money on real high quality tea they'd be broke of course, or prices would have to go up significantly. They have a pretty broad selection. I just went with the House Blend, which was okay. Friends ordered other types and were pleased with theirs. The staff made note of how long we should steep the tea, which was great to see.

If you ever want to have a tea experience that blows your mind -- Brown Hotel in London. DO IT.

quiche.author: Joyce E.
quiche.review:
I was seriously envisioning giving Lovejoy's Tea Room a glowing 5 star review because I love all the cutesy quirky decor, but my best friend and I got the serious runs after visiting this place! I made a reservation for 2 at 2pm on a Thursday afternoon and my best friend and I arrived 15 minutes before our reservation. We were seated right away, but I was a bit disappointed that we were sitting so close to the party next to us because we could hear every single detail of their conversation. We were going to ask if we could move, but the place was packed and we didn't want to seem like snobs!

As per the suggestion of the server, we ordered the High Tea for one and added an extra scone and 2 extra sandwiches with the Yorkshire Gold Tea. The sandwiches we chose were Smoked Turkey and Dijon Mustard, Bay Shrimp and Mayo, Chicken and Asparagus, and Lovejoy's Daily Special, which was probably a ham with some sort of mustard. My BFF and I looked at each other thinking "this is just an appetizer" because the portions were very tiny. Yes, I do understand that tea is supposed to be light, but seriously, the portions were way to small! The Yorkshire Gold Tea was fantastic and definitely enough to share between 2 people. Also, the scones were some of the best I've had!

As we were eating and chatting about life, I noticed that I felt a tad bit hot halfway through. Thinking it was the tea and lack of ventilation on our side, I ignored it and started to feel this way throughout the remaining portion of our tea time. We paid, left, and my stomach started making odd noises. I ignored it until an hour passed and my BFF and I ran to the shiny porcelain throne and girl, let me tell you, it definitely felt like we were reenacting the scene from White Chicks when Brittany or Tiffany Wilson was holding on for her life when she had the quiche. Definitely NOT  a pretty look! It was my first time taking Pepto Bismol and I was not happy.

Again I really do hate to be that person giving 2 stars on a highly rated establishment, but Lovejoy's, you let me down. Would I come back? Probably not!

I want to try the Shepherd's Pie next time!
:P
I think the scone and spreads were my favorite part lol!
I can't wait to come back!
quiche.author: Michelle L.
quiche.review: Came here for the first time a couple weeks ago with a group of girlfriends (4 ppl) for a belated bday celebration. It was a lot of fun and I think everyone enjoyed themselves! I'd def recommend going for the Queen's Tea so you'll get a bit of everything. We all ordered the Queen's Tea, sausage rolls & a quiche. I'm not surprised that we finished everything!!! I want to try the Shepherd's Pie next time! :P I think the scone and spreads were my favorite part lol! I can't wait to come back!

excerpts: In addition to their tea service, they also serve standard British fare like sausage rolls, ploughman's, pasties, shepherd's pie, and quiche.
quiche.author: Steph L.
quiche.review:
Lovejoy's is such a charming place to go for high tea. It's a place you would wear your Sunday clothes to, complete with grandma's pearls, hat, and lace gloves. Their mismatched tea sets add a nice quirky touch too!

In addition to their tea service, they also serve standard British fare like sausage rolls, ploughman's, pasties, shepherd's pie, and quiche. My mom and I shared a shepherd's pie and a Queen's Tea.

The SHEPHERD'S PIE was amazing! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=PeTed6UBTWeBk7jEVkTkLw) Perfectly seasoned ground beef topped with creamy mashed potatoes. And pretty too! The mashed potato is artfully swirled onto the top - details like this really add to their charm :)

The QUEEN'S TEA (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=A8V8DoiszacJREq7-b0w0g) was pretty good. It came with everything I wanted to try. I had a really hard time choosing the sandwiches because they had such a big selection! (Not that I'm complaining). The coleslaw and spring greens were aiight (I'm not what you would call a "salad girl"). The scone and tea biscuit were also good, but mostly because of the fabulous fruit preserves and lemon curd. My favourite was the crumpet though. They brought it out later, freshly out of the toaster. Amazing texture - crispy on the outside, soft and chewy on the inside. We also got our choice of petit four at the end and I chose the cutest one (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=dZd79TtAvold1OhQdyiesQ).

All in all, Lovejoy's is a great place to go for afternoon tea - charming neighbourhood and decor, unpretentious, good selection of food, and not ridiculously overpriced.

excerpts: This time I tried the quiche which was cheesy and rich and flavorful.
I highly recommend it.
The pear and stilton, and the roast beef and horseradish sandwiches were absolutely delicious as well.
It was a lovely afternoon.
quiche.author: Desiree A.
quiche.review:
Attentive service and phenomenal food.  I just can't say enough good things about Lovejoys.  

I enjoyed afternoon tea here for my birthday on August 18th. 

This time I tried the quiche which was cheesy and rich and flavorful.  I highly recommend it.  The pear and stilton, and the roast beef and horseradish sandwiches were absolutely delicious as well.  It was a lovely afternoon.

excerpts: The four of us shared the quiche,  hight tea for two, and another order of scones.
The quiche was okay;  savory and a little fever with egg  cheese and potatoes.
The scones were sublime and as large as hamburger buns; this is the best feature.
The sandwiches were too tiny and nothing special as the turkey and ham meats are
the sky deli meats you get from a grocery store.
I kid you not: the sandwiches are the size of two McDonald's chicken nuggets.
The white peach tea was very tasty.
The black vanilla lavender is actually very pleasant too and was soothing and not at all perfume.
quiche.author: Lorenzo V.
quiche.review: My family and I had a pleasant dining experience,  but the food was mediocre. Service was friendly and the ambience was home like.  The four of us shared the quiche,  hight tea for two, and another order of scones.  The quiche was okay;  savory and a little fever with egg  cheese and potatoes.  Each high tea cubes with a scone, two sandwiches,  salad, coleslaw,  and a tea biscuit.  The scones were sublime and as large as hamburger buns; this is the best feature.  The sandwiches were too tiny and nothing special as the turkey and ham meats are the sky deli meats you get from a grocery store.  I kid you not: the sandwiches are the size of two McDonald's chicken nuggets. The white peach tea was very tasty.  The black vanilla lavender is actually very pleasant too and was soothing and not at all perfume.

excerpts: The scones with lemon curd, fresh cream, and homemade preserves are my favorite menu item...but the tiny sandwiches, quiche, fresh fruits and sweet treats are lovely, too.
The atmosphere is the best--antique furniture, beautiful old china (every teapot, cup, and saucer is different), and lovely sunlight streaming through the windows makes this perch unforgettable.
The red vanilla tea is as good as it gets...buy some across the street at Lovejoys attic and take a bit of the tea room home!
You need a reservation!
quiche.author: Catherine P.
quiche.review: One of my most favorite spots in town. A great place to go with a group of girls or your best friend, daughter, or niece...but not your boyfriend or husband. This girlie tea house is as authentic as they get outside of London. Try the Queen's tea...and you'll enjoy a little taste of everything. The scones with lemon curd, fresh cream, and homemade preserves are my favorite menu item...but the tiny sandwiches, quiche, fresh fruits and sweet treats are lovely, too. The atmosphere is the best--antique furniture, beautiful old china (every teapot, cup, and saucer is different), and lovely sunlight streaming through the windows makes this perch unforgettable. The red vanilla tea is as good as it gets...buy some across the street at Lovejoys attic and take a bit of the tea room home! You need a reservation!

excerpts: The scones were really good though!
At the end of our brunch we found the hat rack and decided to snap some photos.
I think it's a cute tough to have these out for everyone to borrow and feel a little tea-ready!
Overall, cute place
and I would be back if I had another event to attend!
scones.author: Emily C.
scones.review:
Hosted my belated birthday party brunch here! The process was super smooth and I made reservations ahead of time to accommodate a larger party. Gina was the one emailing me back and forth and though I was somewhat unresponsive (I'm sorry!) due to not getting voicemails in time and just being bad at responding to emails because work was busy.. she was still very helpful and friendly! 

We chose the high tea package option and we were able to pick different teas during our brunch. Nobody got too creative and I think we only ordered the white tea in addition to what was already on the table (this was good though!) but Gina also brought us out a pumpkin tea. 

Finger sandwiches were decent but nothing too extraordinary but I think you are mostly paying for the ambiance anyway. The scones were really good though! At the end of our brunch we found the hat rack and decided to snap some photos. I think it's a cute tough to have these out for everyone to borrow and feel a little tea-ready! Overall, cute place and I would be back if I had another event to attend!

excerpts: Like most high teas, the Queen's tea came with scones, crumpets, lemon curd, fruit preserves/jam, and Devon cream.
I really liked that it also came with fresh fruit.
scones.author: Vira P.
scones.review:
My friend and I love checking out all the high tea places San Francisco offers.  This one has been on my list for quite some time, especially because I've seen it in several magazines and travel shows.

I, too, recommend going to Lovejoy's Tea Room for high tea.  They definitely have their aesthetic down.  The atmosphere is very English grandma.  There's cute knick knacks everywhere, and they even have hats available for you to wear while you dine!

What I like about their menu is that you can choose your sandwiches.  I don't eat beef, and there have been some times where I can't substitute items without changing my entire order.  I got the turkey with dijon mustard and artichoke hummus for my Queen's tea.  They were both very good.  The Queen's tea also came with a salad and coleslaw.  I wasn't a fan of the salad because it has arugula.  I'm not an fan of it, but it did go well with the coleslaw, which had the right amount of dressing.  I'm glad there was salad, though, because I needed some greens with this meal.

Like most high teas, the Queen's tea came with scones, crumpets, lemon curd, fruit preserves/jam, and Devon cream.  I really liked that it also came with fresh fruit.  You also get a tea biscuit and your choice of a petit four at the end.

Some of the other places I've gone to were heavy on the desserts.  Lovejoy's isn't, which is fantastic.  I usually feel like I'm going into diabetic shock, but I felt that dining hear was well balanced.

And as for the tea, I got blood orange, and it was delicious.  I didn't need any sugar at all.  

Service was fantastic.  I felt welcomed and well taken care of.

I suggest making reservations as this place is very popular.  And give yourself at least 30 minutes to find parking if you're driving.

excerpts: We had a lovely tea here today, ordered the cream tea and the scones were AMAZING!
A relaxed spot, whether you're famished or just want some scones and a bottomless pot of your favorite tea!
We will definitely be back for more!
scones.author: Val S.
scones.review: We had a lovely tea here today, ordered the cream tea and the scones were AMAZING! A relaxed spot, whether you're famished or just want some scones and a bottomless pot of your favorite tea! We will definitely be back for more!

excerpts: The scones were quite delicious and matches well with the teas.
scones.author: Angie N.
scones.review:
If you have never been to afternoon tea before, like I had not before coming here, I think you'll really enjoy it. This place is very quaint and cute. It's ambience is like quirky british grandparents. This place is great for a group of gal pals wanting to gossip and catch up. You feel kind of fancy, but also just whimsical. They also have a store next door where you can buy paraphernalia and teas. 

The teas were quite tasty and flavorful. The teapots were decently sized and the food is decent. At a tea place, I wouldn't expect the most delicious food but it's bite-sized and lets you have fun with it. The scones were quite delicious and matches well with the teas. There is also a good variety of food items and tea to choose from.

The Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad and Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese sandwiches were my favorite. The tea service options can get a bit pricey, but you are paying for the uniqueness of the experience here. Definitely need a reservation if you're trying to go at all over the weekend. 

Positives:
+ Unique experience
+ Variety of food and teas

Negatives:
- Can get pricy

Recommend:
+ Scone with Preserves and Devon Cream
+ Chestnut tea & Earl grey tea
+ Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad sandwich
+ Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese sandwich

scones.author: Ashley F.
scones.review:
This place is cute. After having my first official afternoon tea in London during our honeymoon, I was dying for another opportunity to enjoy such an experience. My husband is the greatest and made reservations at this spot. What a sport - he was the only guy in the joint and didn't complain, just let me enjoy my tea. 

I had the Me Tea - a bottomless pot (although I could only handle one pot) of brown rice and popcorn green tea, a scone with butter and jam, and a tomato and cheddar sandwich. The presentation was adorable although a bit more rustic than our fancy London experience. I love the character of all mismatched serve ware but was a little bummed about the cleanliness (a stained ring around the rim of my husband's tea cup prior to pouring tea, sediment buildup at the bottom of my tea pot) but it is fine. We are talking about tea in San Francisco, not a high end spot in London. My tea was delicious and the scone was probably one of the best I've had. 

Midway through, I started to get a mild allergic reaction (light swelling of my lips but nothing crazy). I have a nut allergy and didn't think to mention it before ordering since what I ordered should have been nut free - totally my fault and not at all theirs - but when I asked if anything had nuts, the server quickly responded "no" and carried on. I popped a benedryl and continued on enjoying my tea. It would have been nice to know so that I can let you guys know and be aware for myself next time that maybe the butter had ground walnuts (sounds crazy but I've experienced this elsewhere before), or the scones were made with almond flour, but got no such explanation. If you have an allergy, I would be sure to ask first and clearly state so if you have a severe allergy but also be prepared just in case. 

The worst part, the thing that warrants a 3-star review, was the service in my opinion. It felt VERY rushed even though they weren't busy. We had reservations and were immediately seated - awesome. We ordered shortly thereafter and our food arrived within a few minutes - okay great. But then, as I was finishing my food and sipping my tea, the check arrived. I didn't even have time to order another pot if I wanted to, it just felt so rushed. We still sat there for another 10 minutes after paying because I wanted to finish the pot I was currently on (afterall, at $10 a pot, you should be able to enjoy more than a cup or two). I think we were there for a total of 40 minutes. That combined with the nonchalance of the allergy mention above made me a little bummed about the customer service.

Nonetheless it is a cute place and I'd hope you'd have a better experience than we did. I'd say we'd give it another shot, but there are other tea places that I will likely want to try instead to get an experience worthy of the price tag that comes with an afternoon tea.

excerpts: I ordered cream tea, which came with two scones, about a scant tablespoon of clotted cream, a little bit of jam, and some fresh fruit.
A tablespoon of clotted cream is not enough for one scone, never mind for two.
There should have been at least three times that much clotted cream.
I am not exaggerating or being facetious.
You want to be able to spread a thick amount of clotted cream and then have enough left to lick out of the container like a barbarian, if you can get away with it.
Inexplicably, the scones were heated up.
I realize it says that on the menu and perhaps I ought not to have been surprised.
But I was surprised because scones should not be warmed up.
They should be fresh, but not warm and certainly not re-warmed.
Rewarming scones is just not done.
I don't know how else to put that.
It's incorrect.
Aside from it being not done, it's also a bad idea because it will melt your delicious clotted cream and ruin its texture and coolness.
It also can't be good for the texture of the scones.

These were raisin scones, which in my experience are sometimes a bit more solid rather than crumbly, and maybe if they had not been re-heated they would have been on the far end of the acceptable range of scone textures.
They were not the right texture.
They utterly lacked any crumbliness.
Sure, if you're used to Starbucks scones, you might be impressed.
But if you are expecting an English style scone, these are not that.
To summarize, there was not enough clotted cream and the scones were wrong.
scones.author: AK K.
scones.review:
Sub-par cream tea, I'm afraid. 

Considering how cute the place looks, and how busy, and how good the reviews are, I was expecting something wonderful and invited an out-of-town guest for an afternoon tea. We walked in on a weekday afternoon and were immediately seated. It wasn't busy at all. As everyone says it's quite another matter on weekends. The service was perfectly fine. The food and the tea were sub-par.

I feel I must explain what Cream Tea is before I review what I was served.  A cream tea doesn't mean tea which is creamy. A cream tea is a scone served with clotted cream, optionally (though usually) also jam, and a pot of tea. It is a kind of set piece. Clotted cream is a kind of delicious creamy thing about halfway between the most delicate butter you've ever had and whipped cream. It is, not too put too fine a point on it, the very heart of cream tea. You want a generous amount of it. I know all this from having had a great deal of cream tea in England in a variety of tea places. 

I ordered cream tea, which came with two scones, about a scant tablespoon of clotted cream, a little bit of jam, and some fresh fruit. A tablespoon of clotted cream is not enough for one scone, never mind for two. There should have been at least three times that much clotted cream. I am not exaggerating or being facetious. You want to be able to spread a thick amount of clotted cream and then have enough left to lick out of the container like a barbarian, if you can get away with it. I understand that they are importing clotted cream in tiny jars from the UK at great expense, but considering how much the whole cream tea costs, I think they could afford to be more generous with the stuff. It's also possible to make your own clotted cream from scratch, and the only problem is you have to make rather a lot of it at once which shouldn't be such an issue for a shop that specializes in tea. 

Inexplicably, the scones were heated up. I realize it says that on the menu and perhaps I ought not to have been surprised. But I was surprised because scones should not be warmed up. They should be fresh, but not warm and certainly not re-warmed. Rewarming scones is just not done. I don't know how else to put that. It's incorrect. Aside from it being not done, it's also a bad idea because it will melt your delicious clotted cream and ruin its texture and coolness. It also can't be good for the texture of the scones. 

These were raisin scones, which in my experience are sometimes a bit more solid rather than crumbly, and maybe if they had not been re-heated they would have been on the far end of the acceptable range of scone textures. They were not the right texture. They utterly lacked any crumbliness. Sure, if you're used to Starbucks scones, you might be impressed. But if you are expecting an English style scone, these are not that. They are incorrect.

The jam was fine, though still a little bit less than I would really expect.

To summarize, there was not enough clotted cream and the scones were wrong.

Now let us move on to the tea. I ordered the house blend black tea, and it was a very good full-bodied tea. Milk was provided, as it should be. It was loose-leaf and came in a teapot. You had to strain it with a little strainer when pouring because the leaves are put directly in the teapot. Which is OK and I can't say it's not correct, lots of English people do it that way.

The tea was good for the first cup. Because there was no way to take out the tea leaves, it inevitably became over-brewed for subsequent cups. When I got very close to the bottom of the teapot, the waitress came by to "warm up" the pot to make good on the promise of bottomless tea. I can't be 100% sure about what happened next. Based on the flavor of the tea it seems like the old tea leaves were not replaced and either more hot water was added or more hot water with some more leaves. Anyway it was bitter and not very good a that point. The whole tea part of the experience could be improved by putting the looseleaf tea in a brewing basket (which is not heretical in any way and lots of English tea houses do it, and it's not like authenticity appears to be a concern at this teahouse). 

Everything that went wrong could be fixed with a little bit of effort and care. That's part of why I'm writing this review. I'd love for nothing more than to be able to pay slightly too much money for a very good cream tea without flying all the way to England.

Anyway, I'm sure lots of people will continue to have a nice time playing dress-up and doing England cosplay at this highly atmospheric cute little joint. Heck, maybe the sandwiches are good.

excerpts: I ordered a Cream Tea, a Tea pot and scones, to my delight I also got some fresh fruit with that.
scones.author: Tabitha D.
scones.review:
This was a lovely way to spend a Sunday afternoon.
I made it in just before the kitchen closed for the day.

I had finished up at Dolores park and wanted to check out something I had bookmarked that was near. 

I am so happy it was here.

I ordered a Cream Tea, a Tea pot and scones, to my delight I also got some fresh fruit with that.

The pot itself was much larger then i am used to receiving at these types of establishments. 
The decorations are adorable and the staff was attentive.
The scone was delicious, my only down side was the scone comes with devon cream and jam, which is good and all but my preferred is lemon curd with.

Lighting is good, not to cramped.
If i come again by myself I will for sure be bringing a good book. It is a great place to sit and read and enjoy your pot of tea. 

Price isn't awful either :D

excerpts: Perfect if you want something lighter or if you're not into the usual scones, crumpets and sandwiches.
scones.author: Jessie L.
scones.review:
Solid afternoon tea. Nothing particularly special about the food or even the tea, but Lovejoy's has that cozy afternoon tea vibe and is a good spot for catching up with a friend or gathering for a birthday. It's definitely more about the company and experience than the actual food or tea.

That being said, it's kind of an expensive experience, with the cheapest tea services being about $20 and the full tea service (Queen's Tea) being $30. It's easy to make a similar experience at home for much less, but obviously without the quirky decorations around.

I ordered the HEALTHY TEA ($20), which was a large platter consisting of salad, carrots and cucumber, fruit, walnuts, crackers, cream cheese and an option of smoked salmon or artichoke hummus. Perfect if you want something lighter or if you're not into the usual scones, crumpets and sandwiches.

For my tea, I got the Black Vanilla with Lavender, which was recommended by our waitress. Couldn't really taste the lavender but it had a subtle sweetness reminiscent of vanilla. They're very good about refilling your tea pot so it's really bottomless.

Note that they do have a 2 hour limit on the tables! There's also only 1 bathroom and a consistently long line so don't wait until the last moment to get in line.

excerpts: The rest of the meal was delicious (mmm those scones though), and my mom loved the whole experience.
Such a cute/fun afternoon!
scones.author: Catherine S.
scones.review:
I brought my mom here for an early mother's day meal & we had the best time! The decor is super whimsical- mismatched teacups, christmas lights, and british memorabilia. 
I made reservations for 3PM on a Thursday, and when we arrived the restaurant was about 1/3-1/2 full. The restaurant itself is pretty tiny, so I would make reservations just in case. 
We both ordered the queen's tea (2 sandwiches, cabbage salad, fruit, scone, crumpet, petit four & biscuit, and of course a bottomless pot of tea). This was a TON of food! I didn't love the sandwiches I chose, but there are a ton to pick from so I'd love to come back and try some of the others. The rest of the meal was delicious (mmm those scones though), and my mom loved the whole experience. Such a cute/fun afternoon!

excerpts: Highlight: scones, Devon cream, lemon curd, crumpet and petite four.
Ordered the following sandwiches: cucumber cream cheese, mandarin cream cheese, ham and mustard, turkey and mustard.
I personally like the cucumber and mandarin sandwiches because they are light and refreshing.
scones.author: Stephanie L.
scones.review:
So cute. So quaint. My favorite place for high tea. 

We ordered the Queen's tea because we get a little bit of everything. Highlight: scones, Devon cream, lemon curd, crumpet and petite four. Ordered the following sandwiches: cucumber cream cheese, mandarin cream cheese, ham and mustard, turkey and mustard. I personally like the cucumber and mandarin sandwiches because they are light and refreshing. We ordered the savory sandwiches with a little punch of flavor to complement the lighter fare. 

The staff are so nice and accommodating. As it is high tea, we sat for about 2 hours. Staff checked on us regularly enough. We refilled our tea twice (we drink A LOT of tea). 

You get a little coupon to their retail storefront across the street Lovejoy's Attic when you dine.

excerpts: For high tea for 12 (13), we were able to pick any teas off of the menu, and due to our large party we had a preorder selection of six kinds of sandwiches, along with salad, scones and cream, and tea biscuits.
The salad was just some greens, nothing too special, but the scones were solid and the sandwiches as well.
scones.author: Wayne H.
scones.review:
We had a large reservation for two birthdays here, but they were really good with helping me over the phone while making the reservation and with service while we were here. We had 12 adults plus a baby, so we were posted up in their largest table. It's a little bit cramped inside because it is chock full of decor, hats, and additional tables, but it wasn't much of a hassle.

For high tea for 12 (13), we were able to pick any teas off of the menu, and due to our large party we had a preorder selection of six kinds of sandwiches, along with salad, scones and cream, and tea biscuits. The salad was just some greens, nothing too special, but the scones were solid and the sandwiches as well.

We got the following sandwiches: Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad, Roast Beef & Horseradish, Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese, Lovejoy's Daily Special, Bay Shrimp & Mayonnaise, Pear & Stilton. They were all pretty solid, but the smoked salmon & cream cheese and the daily special were definitely the favorites.

The tea selection were all pretty solid as well, and they were pretty good with getting us more hot water or more teapots as we asked for different flavors of teas.

Many thanks for the flexibility in accommodating our large party, especially when we weren't sure how large the party was going to be during the reservation process.

excerpts: They seem to have gotten the food right now with Sandwiches, scones, and salads.
They seem to have ironed out the kinks in the food since they took over from the original owner.

Earlier--
September 2016: 
Scones much improved.
Perhaps it's an entirely different purveyor that they are acquiring them from?
Service good as always.
The main problem: the scented products in the bathroom.
The first of our party to go in there came back and warned us.
I went and asked someone about it for going in.
Finally I had to talk to the owner and she removed the products.
Honestly, it's a tiny space and I have a medical issue.
But even my friend-- she couldn't breathe, her head aching afterwards.
Along with the two scones which were undercooked, we received the usual raspberry jam, watery whipping cream which did not barely fill the thimble size container, and no lemon curd.
They have added a few sandwiches to the menu, which is fine.
I would not make any more changes at the moment, and instead concentrate on maintaining quality.
Service was good as usual, attentive, lovely, personable.
Sandwiches were good.
Tea good.
scones.author: Cleo B.
scones.review:
Dec 2017:
No apologies on the horrible service. Server only topped off our tea hot water one time during 1 hr 45 mins. Server did not check in with us after initial serving. 

Rushed: Then, we are not done eating at 1 hr in, and the server comes by with desert tray. I wanted to say that we weren't quite ready for it, that we felt rushed, but instead we said no thank you. Shortly after that the check appeared on our table.

One of the two new owners stopped by, saying "I hear there's been a problem." I explain the situation to her. No recognition at all that something has changed in their service or that there's something amiss. 

She then tells me that we are supposed to flag down the server if we want more hot water for our tea. Since when? Like many of you I have been to tea rooms in many places, in many places, including England. And nowhere does the customer have to flag the server down for hot water. It is their job to come by and do a refill.

The Correct attitude of the new owner would be to say, yes I understand that we haven't done enough, our service has not been up to standards. The fact is, since the new ownership, the service has actually been fine. Why it was different this time I don't know. I have been here before Christmas with the new owners, so it can't be that. It's the attitude that I don't appreciate. After years of enjoying this place under the former owners tutelage, this new situation is sad.

Food: They seem to have gotten the food right now with Sandwiches, scones, and salads. They seem to have ironed out the kinks in the food since they took over from the original owner. I'm sad to say that the service is driving me and others away from this business.

Earlier--
September 2016: 
Scones much improved. Perhaps it's an entirely different purveyor that they are acquiring them from? Service good as always. 
The main problem: the scented products in the bathroom. The first of our party to go in there came back and warned us. I went and asked someone about it for going in. Finally I had to talk to the owner and she removed the products. Honestly, it's a tiny space and I have a medical issue. But even my friend-- she couldn't breathe, her head aching afterwards. I could see having the usual scented soap in there has a lingering effect, but please consider people who can't abide by scented products let alone blasting it in a small space. 

August 2016:
New owners have taken charge. No more Muna! Please give them feedback so that they can maintain this wonderful business. 
Along with the two scones which were undercooked, we received the usual raspberry jam, watery whipping cream which did not barely fill the thimble size container, and no lemon curd. They have added a few sandwiches to the menu, which is fine. I would not make any more changes at the moment, and instead concentrate on maintaining quality. Service was good as usual, attentive, lovely, personable. Sandwiches were good. Tea good.

excerpts: I think the next time that I come here I will go straight for the tea and scones.
scones.author: Sean A.
scones.review:
Made reservations for Lovejoy's on their website for 11 AM. Be sure to do the same. When we arrived the tables were all reserved. 

The restaurant is outfitted with English decor. There is a hat rack with hats that you might be able to wear. 

We opted for the High tea. There is another higher level set with more food. But, we ended up really being stuffed, so I'd recommend the High tea unless you are absolutely starving. It's much cheaper too. 

Our server was nice and friendly and suggested teas and sandwiches that we might like. There was another server that did, however, give a far more detailed explanation of the menu to another party. 

For tea, I chose Chestnut. My girlfriend chose Apricot. Mine wasn't suited to me. My girlfriend, being awesome as she is, tried mine and liked it, so we switched. I really liked the Apricot. They freshen up the tea for you after a bit and give you huge potfuls. 

I was able to choose two sandwiches for my set. The two that I chose were salmon and chicken salad with walnuts. The sandwiches were good not great. 

Also included was a wonderful cabbage salad with Carraway cream dressing. I scarfed that one down. 

The organic spring greens were a little wilted. 

The highlight of the set had to be the scone! Nice and warm with currants. I recommend spooning some Devon cream and preserves on each bite. Super yummy!

I think the next time that I come here I will go straight for the tea and scones. I'd like to try a crumpet as well!

excerpts: The scones were pretty good - which is what I came for.
I think it was overpriced for the amount of food and quality.
The decor was very cute but kind of old (frays and stains).
Maybe I was expecting too much, but it definitely doesn't compare to tea service in the UK.
scones.author: Tina G.
scones.review: We got a Queens Tea and a High Tea set. The food was decent but nothing special. The scones were pretty good - which is what I came for. I think it was overpriced for the amount of food and quality. The decor was very cute but kind of old (frays and stains). Maybe I was expecting too much, but it definitely doesn't compare to tea service in the UK.

excerpts: The teas were amazing and the food, and the scones were the best scones I have ever had in my life.
Definitely coming back here when we are in SF.
This is a great place for little girls they also have hats and decor to wear while you are in there.
scones.author: Madeeha B.
scones.review: We have been trying to go here for years when we used to live in Sacramento and never had the opportunity. We were in town for a wedding and decided to stop by they were all full and we didn't have a reservation but we told them that we were really wanting to go here for years, they made an accommodation although it was small it was perfect. The teas were amazing and the food, and the scones were the best scones I have ever had in my life. Definitely coming back here when we are in SF. This is a great place for little girls they also have hats and decor to wear while you are in there.

excerpts: We ordered two sets Queen's tea which had fruits, salad, scones, sandwiches, and crumpets.
The scones were scrumptious (especially with lemon curd) and the tea sandwiches were divine (my fave was the egg and onions and the apple and cream cheese)!
We tried the peppermint tea, and the peach green tea- both very good and refreshing.
Definitely a good place to hang out when you are in Noe Valley.
scones.author: Notsky P.
scones.review: A perfect spot to enjoy afternoon tea with friends.  Our reservations was at 4pm but I came 15 minutes early.  Not an issue as they have our tables ready and promptly seated me while I wait for the rest of my party.  The decor was on point and the mismatched tea sets were adorable!  We ordered two sets Queen's tea which had fruits, salad, scones, sandwiches, and crumpets.  The scones were scrumptious (especially with lemon curd) and the tea sandwiches were divine (my fave was the egg and onions and the apple and cream cheese)!  We tried the peppermint tea, and the peach green tea- both very good and refreshing.  Definitely a good place to hang out when you are in Noe Valley.

excerpts: It comes with fresh fruit two sandwiches, salad, coleslaw, scones, crumpets tea cookies and petite fours and of course a bottomless pot of your choice of tea.
The Queens tea was about ~$29 per person.
You can't go wrong with the tea, and their scones are so good and buttery and are warm when you get them.
We got the smoked salmon/cream cheese, chicken walnut apple and pear and Stilton sandwiches.
The smoked salmon was delicious, pear was ok
and I would skip the chicken walnut apple next time.
Their fruit was sweet and the coleslaw lacked flavor and the salad was just the greens, mandarin oranges with balsamic vinaigrette.
The crumpets come half way through and we're nice and hot.
The petite fours were sweet and a nice touch to the end.
Over all I would come again but maybe just get the tea, scones, a crumpet and maybe even one sandwich.
scones.author: Michelle P.
scones.review: I ordered the queens tea. It comes with fresh fruit two sandwiches, salad, coleslaw, scones, crumpets tea cookies and petite fours and of course a bottomless pot of your choice of tea. The Queens tea was about ~$29 per person. You can't go wrong with the tea, and their scones are so good and buttery and are warm when you get them. We got the smoked salmon/cream cheese, chicken walnut apple and pear and Stilton sandwiches. The smoked salmon was delicious, pear was ok and I would skip the chicken walnut apple next time. Their fruit was sweet and the coleslaw lacked flavor and the salad was just the greens, mandarin oranges with balsamic vinaigrette. The crumpets come half way through and we're nice and hot. The petite fours were sweet and a nice touch to the end. Over all I would come again but maybe just get the tea, scones, a crumpet and maybe even one sandwich.

excerpts: while the sweet items (scones are DIVINE) lever a balance between sips of bottomless teas.
scones.author: Miika M.
scones.review:
Fantastic little outing, especially for moms/girls/friends looking to partake in the classic tea time experience with with the Alice in Wonderland feel.

Everything here reminds me of a distant friend's attic full of small treasures and collectibles from family moves and heirlooms.  The mismatched approach creates an even more cute and colorful palette, rustic right down to the chairs and tables.

Service her is warm and friendly so be prepared to be pampered.  Please note that this establishment gets packed quickly and if you don't have reservations, good luck trying to do a walk-in.  People make reservations here in advance.

We ordered the Queen's Tea Service, which is an assortment of both savory and sweet items.  The savory sandwiches are cut cleanly in quarters and are devoid of crust *yay* while the sweet items (scones are DIVINE) lever a balance between sips of bottomless teas.

Cute outing with the girls and definitely affordable (tea service in Paris and London were costing me a cool $100 at least) so it was nice to partake in something local that was quite affordable.

excerpts: The mini sandwiches and scones provided tasted very fresh.
scones.author: Vanessa S.
scones.review:
What a perfect place for a tea party! I came here for a meet up, place was easy to get too (parking wasn't too hard find), the service was very attentive, and the inside decor was very quaint. Plus there was plenty of space so you didn't all feel on top of each other.

The mini sandwiches and scones provided tasted very fresh. Since we had a large group I could sample of all the black and herbal teas since the group like those the most.

Would recommend this place for anyone wanting to have a tea party, tea date, or just want tea!

excerpts: We ordered one High Tea service to share; this included the choice of two tea sandwiches, small salad, cabbage slaw, and two scones with clotted cream and berry preserves.
For the sandwiches we went for the sweet and savory: the pear and stilton & the special of the day fig tapenade with goat cheese.
Both were delicious!
For our bottomless pot o' tea --the "champagne of teas" was elected: Afternoon Darjeeling.
This really was bottomless as a server would check it periodically and warm it (put more hot water in) to assure that we didn't run out in the middle of our tea service.
The presentation of the tea service was on a two-tiered stand --which gave a nice 360 view of your items to pick and choose as you ate.
**some tables are a bit smaller and may get a bit crowded as items come  out from the kitchen, so maneuver carefully --definitely wouldn't want to break anything!
scones.author: Vanessa G.
scones.review:
I am so happy to finally be able to write a review for Lovejoy's Tea Room.  The first and last time I came was nearly 15 years ago for a birthday party; at the time, I was ten and loved the experience.  I kept eyeing this place for years and finally my best friend and I decided to catch up and we were able to book a table at Lovejoy's for the same week --a Wednesday at 3pm.  We went yesterday and loved every minute.  

Upon first arriving it was such a charming view to see all the tables and chairs set up with their cups, saucers, and small plates.  The mismatched china is fun to look at and compare.  The tables had a lace tablecloth and honestly, I felt like I would be joined by Jane Austen any minute.  The set up is wonderful!

The host and server was very friendly and gave us her recommendations to order our tea service.  We ordered one High Tea service to share; this included the choice of two tea sandwiches, small salad, cabbage slaw, and two scones with clotted cream and berry preserves. For the sandwiches we went for the sweet and savory: the pear and stilton & the special of the day fig tapenade with goat cheese.  Both were delicious! For our bottomless pot o' tea --the "champagne of teas" was elected: Afternoon Darjeeling.  This really was bottomless as a server would check it periodically and warm it (put more hot water in) to assure that we didn't run out in the middle of our tea service.  The presentation of the tea service was on a two-tiered stand --which gave a nice 360 view of your items to pick and choose as you ate.  
**some tables are a bit smaller and may get a bit crowded as items come  out from the kitchen, so maneuver carefully --definitely wouldn't want to break anything!** 

My friend and I enjoyed the whole experience and even looking around at the decor is fun! There is so many unique and fun items hanging around.  

Although they tea room was not very busy when we went, I'd definitely recommend making a reservation to secure a table especially for the weekends because there is usually a crowd gathered outside waiting whenever I drive by.  

My friend and I agreed to return again and soon!  We'd love to visit around the holidays as well.  There is something truly special about sipping tea here --I definitely recommend.

excerpts: The service is outstanding, and the scones were really buttery and flaky.
scones.author: Carolyn H.
scones.review: This place was unexpected and pretty charming. It is like being at grandma's house. Lots of breakable items on doilies and a pillow for everyone's back. Even the bathroom was dolled up. This is like playing tea party as a kid, but with food that is not imaginary. The service is outstanding, and the scones were really buttery and flaky. Took me a bit to figure out the sandwiches on the platter for high tea, but all in all it was a huge spread that left us full for the afternoon. Chicken salad was a favorite, but I thought it was just okay. The pear and Gorgonzola and the tea (apricot and chestnut) were excellent. The chestnut tea was almost like drinking maple syrup without the sweet. The salad was yummy-I liked that it wasn't dressed, but I didn't much care for the slaw-although my boyfriend liked it.

excerpts: We had also scones that came with with jelly and cream.
scones.author: Tiffany K.
scones.review:
My girlfriends and I decided to try this place out for her birthday. I honestly don't recall anything that WOW'ed me. I have to say that I was a bit disappointed after trying this place. I've definitely had better tea time . I think this place was hyped up but I'm glad to have tried it at least once. 

I ordered the "High Tea for Two" w/ a black lavender tea. Again I was not really impressed with the tea. I couldn't taste nor smell the lavender even though I let it sit for a bit.  The sandwich selection wasn't to my liking but my friend and had two choices each so we decided to share a , cucumber & cream cheese, egg & onion, asparagus & chicken, and salmon & cream cheese. I mean you can go wrong with sandwiches, but I didn't finish  it at all. We had also scones that came with with jelly and cream.

I have to say the chicken & asparagus looked really weird, almost like it was avocado as it was a spread , and the egg  & onion was a bit too much too my liking, (a lot of onions).  The salad was ok, ( can't go wrong with that). There wasn't much that came with this "High Tea" package. 

Overall service was great, I recommend to at least try this place once, parking is easy but this place gets packed quick so make a reservation ahead of time as its very popular.  But I don't think I would come back again unless its a new seasonal menu.

excerpts: The scones at Lovejoy's are AMAZING.
It was served warm and was flaky but not dry.
We devoured the one that came with our tea so we ordered another one for $2.95 and did not regret it at all.
scones.author: Carrie W.
scones.review:
I am officially obsessed with Lovejoy's! I live a few blocks from here and after begging A for MONTHS to go on a tea date with me, he finally gave in and we were able to make a reservation. I will say that I think we may have gotten in earlier had we been able to walk in but Lovejoy's is too popular. I think the reservation process is a bit opaque, however, since you have to request a reservation without knowing which times are available. I wish they were on OpenTable or Resy or at least had a more detailed calendar but I guess there is some charm in having to go through a bit of effort.

Anyways, we requested any available time but noted that we preferred earlier in the day on Saturday rather than later. To our luck, we got a reservation at 11AM right when they opened. When we got there, the place was already pretty full and there was a wedding shower going on at one of the long communal tables. Lovejoy's is SUPER cute on the inside and they have all of these adorable hats you can wear during your tea party. A was not about that AT ALL and felt a bit self-conscious in the admittedly feminine space.

Anyways, we had a difficult time ordering because we didn't want to over-order. We settled on getting one Queen's Tea ($28) and split the bottomless tea pot (+$2) since we both wanted a black tea and it didn't make sense to spend an additional $10 when we would have ordered something similar if not the same thing. We also split the Tea Sandwich Plate ($12.95). The 4 tea sandwich choices we chose between the Queen's Tea and the Plate were the Roast Beef & Horseradish, Chicken-Apple-Walnut Salad, Smoked Salmon and Cream Cheese and the Pear and Stilton. We liked them all with the exception of the Pear and Stilton which had a weird taste. Both sandwich plates also came with a mixed green salad and cabbage slaw both of which were okay if not standard. The Queen's Tea also came with a scone, a crumpet and a petit four. The scones at Lovejoy's are AMAZING. It was served warm and was flaky but not dry. We devoured the one that came with our tea so we ordered another one for $2.95 and did not regret it at all. The crumpet was satisfying and the petit four was cute and the perfect end to our meal. Was it cheap? No. Did A leave hungry? Maybe. But even in the end, he was a convert to the joys of high tea and wants to go experience it at one of the fancy hotels in the city! I cannot wait to come back to Lovejoy's in any case but I wish I could just stop in and get a scone to go :D

excerpts: Good scones and British Tea.
scones.author: Angela B.
scones.review:
Quaint, but actually rather disorganized and messy. The 12.00 minimum per person on the menu is tacky. 
"We're "Haves", we don't have time for a person who just want's a single cup of tea and a scone".
Service is not their strength either. 
Can you say "elitist"? Ick.
Good scones and British Tea.

excerpts: Scones were very delicious, especially with the lemon spread.
Yum!
The teas were really good.
We had two kinds of teas.
One with caffeine and one non caffeine.
I do not remember the names of the teas.
Both were delicious.
scones.author: Lucy L.
scones.review:
This is the cutest place for an afternoon tea party! My cousin made reservations way ahead of time, because we had about 15 guests that day. It was for a special occasion. They allowed her to decorate the tables and dining area we were sitting. Their decor itself is super cute. They definitely know how to make the place look absolutely adorable. 

Food:
I believe she chose the high tea menu, but I could be wrong. She had planned this tea party way beforehand, and had selected a set menu with Lovejoy. There were many selective mini sandwiches; everything was different. Scones were very delicious, especially with the lemon spread. Yum! The teas were really good. We had two kinds of teas. One with caffeine and one non caffeine. I do not remember the names of the teas. Both were delicious. I will definitely come back here again for a tea party!

Service and staff were amazing. They were all very friendly. They would constantly come over to check up on our tea kettles and refill. Overall, an amazing first-time experience.

Parking: it sucked for me. It's just regular street parking. Our reservations was on a Saturday @11am. I circled around the area for 30 darn minutes.... Luckily, I ended up finding parking 3-4 blocks away. Beware of weekend parking! *sigh*

excerpts: The scones are freshly made, as they should be.
They do provide proper clotted / Devonshire cream, and luxurious preserves to smear on your scone.
Scones were good.
Sandwiches were on the small side
so if you order a tea service with 2 included per person I recommend you order one more for the table to share.
Cream cheese is nothing special / has nothing in it (no herbs or seasoning) but the salmon tasted fresh.
Basically the sandwiches are super simple and more like tea at home that auntie made versus tea at a fine tea house.
scones.author: Miriam W.
scones.review:
OK, I'm going to split this into a two-pronged attack!

1) TEA WHORES

If you are a true tea connoisseur and lover and you have at least 5 loose-leaf teas at home in proper temperature controlled and vacuum-sealed containers that did not come to you as a gift in a gift basket, you are a true tea lover. Being a generic tea lover, however, is separate from being a Western-tradition high tea lover, in that, there's East and West. Dimsum-style East, high tea-style West. If you have participated and explored the tea rituals of the west frequently -- you will not see this as five-star place, but you will enjoy it. 

2) GENERAL PUBLIC

It is quaint, it is charming like all the reviews say. The teas are good. Not amazing, but good. The service is ... good enough. It's San Francisco, the place isn't huge. The prices ... are as expected. The ambiance is your dotty grandma's house, stuffed to the gills with tea paraphernalia and family photos, doilies and crochet-work cuddling up the dusty old lampshades. The bathroom is clean and spacious (a rarity in the city). It is filled with many groups of women at various stages of life, from celebrating engagements to graduations to gossiping to catch up. The petit fours are freshly made and moist (I was surprised and impressed by this). The scones are freshly made, as they should be. They do provide proper clotted / Devonshire cream, and luxurious preserves to smear on your scone. They have a good-sized savoury menu aside from tea service.

If you're not a tea whore and don't really take your high tea very seriously, and you rarely do this sort of thing, you'll be satisfied with the environment and you will have fun, and one tea service will generally make you stuffed and happy.

If you ARE a tea whore, you will notice some thangs. They aren't major, but cost the fifth star:

- Service: This place has been around a while and is extremely busy and popular, and it's in the city, so I get the "French maitre'd" vibe that has happened. Let's just say that the vibe I expect when I go to High Tea is generally about ensuring you are calm, comfortable, looked after, and delighted. We had touch points with multiple staff members and only one staff member was happy and pleasant toward us; the rest treated us like they were busy lor annoyed and that worrying about how busy they were was more important than worrying about the experience for the customers they had. They basically expect that making the food, putting the tea in front of you, the decor, and checking on you once suffices. It does not. I highly recommend that if it's possible all the staff members attend a proper tea (I have yet to find one in SF actually, even at highly rated hotels) and once they have their mind blown they'll get it. It's hard to explain. It's about the experience, the ritual, and being catered to, tea time is sacred in England. Originally, it went on for hours. If you are really trying to recreate that experience, you're not there yet. If you're making your own Cali version ... it's good enough.

- Pricing: A quality tea service doesn't charge you extra for a "bottomless pot of tea." It's included in the price of the service. Also it's SF, so I wasn't surprised by how much you pay for what you get, but it's a little on the stingy side (I was letting it go for the foodstuffs but I got offended that you're paying extra for the tea, since that's the whole point of being there).

- Food: For 3 people, they don't give you particularly generous portions of clotted cream or preserves. We are all trying to watch our weight so we didn't ask for more and made do. Salad is generous. The caraway seed (I think that's the spice) is FAR too overused in their coleslaw salad and I'd frankly they not include that salad and expend that on a free petit four for everybody by default. Quiche looked good; we didn't get to try the crumpets. Scones were good. Sandwiches were on the small side so if you order a tea service with 2 included per person I recommend you order one more for the table to share. Cream cheese is nothing special / has nothing in it (no herbs or seasoning) but the salmon tasted fresh. Basically the sandwiches are super simple and more like tea at home that auntie made versus tea at a fine tea house. Tomato and cheese is straight up tomato and cheese - you could make it at home.

- Tea: As mentioned, good, not amazing. If they spent money on real high quality tea they'd be broke of course, or prices would have to go up significantly. They have a pretty broad selection. I just went with the House Blend, which was okay. Friends ordered other types and were pleased with theirs. The staff made note of how long we should steep the tea, which was great to see.

If you ever want to have a tea experience that blows your mind -- Brown Hotel in London. DO IT.

excerpts: The scones and crumpet were so good.
I will definitely be back again and again.
scones.author: Rude G.
scones.review: Excellent as always. Service was great. The scones and crumpet were so good. I will definitely be back again and again.

excerpts: The sandwiches, scones, and fruit were a perfect amount of food.
scones.author: Nicole W.
scones.review:
Lovejoy's is one of the cutest places in SF! I went here with my book club and had such a great time! We ordered variations of the tea service and all got the "bottomless teapots". I got the "Light Tea" with the cucumber sandwiches and loved everything on my plate! The sandwiches, scones, and fruit were a perfect amount of food. It was also so fun to learn more about tea amidst the eclectic decor!

The servers were very sweet and took great care of us. One even shared a heartwarming story about how she got the infamous "cat teapot." Apparently you can request it :)

Love Lovejoy's!

excerpts: Queens tea for two ... warm scones are so good and my fav is the tray of petit four they bring out at the end
scones.author: Jennifer T.
scones.review:
Love this cute tea place.  Been here a few times and can't wait to come back.  Queens tea for two ... warm scones are so good and my fav is the tray of petit four they bring out at the end


Make reservations at least two weeks ahead.  They book up quickly on weekends.

excerpts: I've been to Lovejoy's for the last 20 years and enjoy meeting up with my friends over a great pot of tea and sandwiches/scones.
scones.author: Vali G.
scones.review:
I've been to Lovejoy's for the last 20 years and enjoy meeting up with my friends over a great pot of tea and sandwiches/scones.  I really like the tea room blend - a black caffeinated tea but there are plenty of other teas to choose from.  The sausage rolls are delicious and my favorite sandwich is the chicken and asparagus.  Don't forget the scone with clotted cream and jam.

It's a wonderful place to go to and I hope to enjoy it for the next 20 years or more!

excerpts: the option of lots of different sandwiches, scones with cream, pretty plates, dainty cups.
I met my parents at Lovejoy's feminine little tea room, one of the few open for tea mid-week.
scones.author: Ryen B.
scones.review:
There are so many things I enjoy about high-tea... the option of lots of different sandwiches, scones with cream, pretty plates, dainty cups. I met my parents at Lovejoy's feminine little tea room, one of the few open for tea mid-week. The place was full and the staff was hopping!

Mom and I both ordered high tea. We each got to choose two sandwiches, sliced into 4 triangles each. Lots of filling options to pick from, they came between a slice of white and brown bread, crusts removed. I went with smoked salmon and cream cheese (YUM!) and Branston pickle chutney with cheddar (nice cheddar, but a bit skimpy on the chutney). Mom let me try a piece of her hummus and arugula, which was good, though not as good as the salmon. I didn't try her ham and mustard, but said the mustard was nice and spicy. Dad seemed happy with his roast beef and chicken sandwiches- again, not a sharer. :-(

The sandwiches were arranged around a mixed green salad, fresh and kicked up by the mandarin oranges and a sweet/tangy dressing. The two tiered tray also had a bowl of cabbage salad- a slaw really- with a creamy caraway seed dressing that was also good. 

My fave of the bunch was the currant filled scone which I slathered with devon cream and a bit of raspberry preserves. The tea biscuit was just ok to my taste buds.

We each got a pot of tea. I ordered the chestnut which had a lovely maple aroma, but was a bit weak for my liking, even after steeping quite a while. Glad she didn't add any extra hot water to my pot. I tend to drink a lot of water and the staff was too busy to keep my glass filled. Glad I brought a bottle of my own!

All in all, a nice spot to try if you haven't been before.

excerpts: Naturally, all I wanted to do for my birthday was drink tea and eat scones, so I started hunting for a British tea room in the Bay Area.
Everything was delicious, especially the scones and shepherd's pie.
scones.author: Lily K.
scones.review:
After coming back from London a few months ago, I found myself missing the city and all its delights. Naturally, all I wanted to do for my birthday was drink tea and eat scones, so I started hunting for a British tea room in the Bay Area. My search led to my discovery of Lovejoy's Tea room, where I easily made a reservation online.

The entire shop is charming and reminded me of one of the tea rooms I went to while in London. There's even hats for you to wear if you want to perfect your outfit for the occasion with headgear!
