crumpet.author: Rebecca A.
crumpet.review:
Oh my god, this place is the best tea room I have ever been to. 
let me just preface this by saying that I am part British, and i have been going to tea rooms since i could remember, and i daresay that this is the best tea room i have ever been to. 

The decor is soooo cute, and comfy, and this tea room has a great atmosphere and ambiance. It is just soo cute and comfy, and the people who work there are soo nice, attentive and helpful.

The service is great. the servers are very knowledgeable, helpful, attentive, and nice. They are always checking to make sure your tea is hot, and they are always making sure that the food is good and that you are happy with everything.

I have only ever gotten the queen's tea both times i've gone, and it was amazing both times. 
the first time i got the pear and stilton sandwich and the goat cheese, sundired tomato, and olive sandwich. They were both amazing and satisfaying, and perfectly balance. 
the second time i went i got the hummus and artichoke sandwich and the chutney and cheese sandwich. the hummus was okay, it was nothing special but it hit the spot, and the chutney was perfect. 

their scones were amazing, perfectly flaky, just the right amount of sweetness, and the perfect amount of raisins and currants. they were warm, and fresh, and amazing. the creme, jam, and lemon curd were also amazing and complimented the scones and eachother perfectly. 

the shortbread cookies were sooo good, they were thin and cruncy, and so perfectly sweet. 

the coleslaw is ridiculously delicious. I have never liked coleslaw and i am in love with their coleslaw. their sauce is amazing, and they put just the right amount of sauce on their coleslaw, and the rye seeds they add just make the coleslaw so much better than you would ever think coleslaw could be. 

the fresh fruit they serve is also really delicious, although i wish they gave you more

the crumpets were really good. they were warm and fresh, and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. they were amazing with the lemon curd and the butter. I'm normally not a big crumpet fan, so the second time i went i just got them to give me an extra scone instead of the crumpet, but  you must try the crumpets at least once. 

the petit fours are also amazing. the chocolate truffle with apricot was amazing, the walnut brownie was amazing, and the rose-water was amazing as well. they have a large and delicious petit four selection, and i have loved every single petit four that i have tried. 

finally, their tea selection is amazing. I love their darjeeling, and they always keep your tea hot, and make sure that it's hot. they have a really wide selection of non-caffein teas as well, and they are all delicious. 

lovejoy's just has the greatest atmosphere and service and it is seriously the best tea room I have ever been to out of los angeles and san francisco.

i made my friend who hates tea and pastries go to lovejoy's and she is now in love with tea time. that's how good lovejoy's is, it converted my pastry and tea hating friend to a tea time fanatic.

lovejoy's is a must try if you are ever in the bay area, it is an amazing experience!


just a side note, on the weekends, and even fridays, you should try to make reservations if you can, although they do also take walk-ins.

excerpts: This set came with coleslaw (ehh), organic spring greens (really plain salad), a raisin scone with preserves (yummm!) and double devon cream (a better version of butter), a crumpet with lemon curd (delicioussss and zesty), fresh fruit, and a petit four and a shortbread tea biscuit.
Iono about the crumpet.
Are they supposed to be like half pancake,
half english muffins?
I didn't finish it (even when spread with the lemon curd!)
cause it was just unappetizing.
The fresh fruit had a good variety (strawberries, grapes, grapefruit, blueberries, kiwis).
The petit four was a strawberry shortcake with marzipan.
Very sweet and delicious.
I would give this place 5 stars because of the variety of foods offered, but I didn't like the quality/pairings of all the foods (eg. salad and dressing, crumpet).
crumpet.author: Adorable T.
crumpet.review:
I came here with a party of four on a Sunday afternoon, around 1:35pm, and luckily got seats within 10 minutes (not to mention I got lucky with parking!). The waitress was very pleasant, taking away plates when we were finished, and giving us clean plates so we wouldn't have to mix tastes. She was also very honest in giving her opinion about what was good on the menu vs. what was popular.

I ordered the Queen's Tea and had he China Rose Petal (black tea). I chose the Chicken-Apple-Walnut sandwich and the Smoked Salmon & Cream Cheese sandwiches. This set came with coleslaw (ehh), organic spring greens (really plain salad), a raisin scone with preserves (yummm!) and double devon cream (a better version of butter), a crumpet with lemon curd (delicioussss and zesty), fresh fruit, and a petit four and a shortbread tea biscuit.

The tea was very aromatic. It had just the right amount of flavor. Adding sugar and milk to it made it easier to drink, but I enjoyed it plain.

The sandwiches are are cut into fourths. The chicken-apple-walnut sandwich was quite delicious. It was basically a chicken salad with chunks of apple and walnut. Smoked salmon and cream cheese sandwiches were very normal. The ones I make at home taste about the same. I didn't touch the cole slaw cause I don't like it. The organic spring greens were bitter (as usual), but I didn't like the dressing enough to finish it (lighter type of dressing). The raisin scone is soft on the inside, but has just the right "crunch" on the outside. it went well with the butter and jam, but i was really into the lemon curd. Iono about the crumpet. Are they supposed to be like half pancake, half english muffins? I didn't finish it (even when spread with the lemon curd!) cause it was just unappetizing. The fresh fruit had a good variety (strawberries, grapes, grapefruit, blueberries, kiwis). The petit four was a strawberry shortcake with marzipan. Very sweet and delicious. Shortbread tea biscuit is how you would imagine it to be like, but not as heavy as a "walker's".

I would give this place 5 stars because of the variety of foods offered, but I didn't like the quality/pairings of all the foods (eg. salad and dressing, crumpet). All together, for 2 light tea's and 1 queen's tea was $65 (inc. t&t).

excerpts: This place is special to me because my best friend of 11 years took me here, despite my initial hesitation to pretend I was a 19th century Victorian women and partake in tea and crumpet time.
She passed on in August and I will always remember the great times we shared.
crumpet.author: Alvin T.
crumpet.review:
This place is special to me because my best friend of 11 years took me here, despite my initial hesitation to pretend I was a 19th century Victorian women and partake in tea and crumpet time. She passed on in August and I will always remember the great times we shared. So this review is for you Crissie, love and miss you always.

Upon walking in here I noticed I was one of only two males in this entire place. Crap. After being seated I noticed that the table to my right was "reserved for the princesses" or something along those lines. FML. With my head held high masculinity still in tact, I quickly glanced at the menu and chose the manliest items offered: peppermint tea with the smoked turkey and dijon mustard sandwich. While sipping my tea and taking small bites of my tiny ass sandwich, I couldn't help but think that the only thing I was missing was a dress and crown. Despite feeling out of place, I have to admit that the tea was bomb and the sandwich was like crack on bread.

I think I'll come back here one day, in memory of you Crissie. You took me to some random ass places and we had some good laughs, Love you sooooo much. You'll always be in my heart.

P.S.  When I do return I'll be wearing my blinged out crown and sexy ass corset dress. UH huh, yea, that's right. Imma be Queen BITCH for the day ya'll, sippin on some tea and eating some good ass sandwiches.

excerpts: Their scone/crumpet are quite plain, what makes them delicious is the Devon cream plus the preserves or lemon curd (You can buy the cream next door, I put it on waffles with the lemon curd, $8 for a small jar, eek!).
You get a 10% discount on teas if you dined in the Tea Room.
crumpet.author: Mavi T.
crumpet.review:
Went here on a Sunday for a ladies pre-Valentine day out. I have to say I really enjoyed it here, the whole experience of it all.

The wait was 30mins at noon. We headed over to the antique counterpart next door while waiting, where you can get the Devon cream, lemon curd, and of course the teas! Anyway, that's for another review.

Back in the tea room, the place is tiny so it leans to more of a cramped than cozy feel, but that's your call. Decor reminds me of grandma's. Service is friendly but they do seem to push the time limit a bit much, that you start feeling rushed. Service is quick and the pots are never below half full also, kept at a good temperature, hot. The tea sandwiches are yummy, although quite pricey for the quantities given. At least the teas are bottomless.

Their scone/crumpet are quite plain, what makes them delicious is the Devon cream plus the preserves or lemon curd (You can buy the cream next door, I put it on waffles with the lemon curd, $8 for a small jar, eek!). You get a 10% discount on teas if you dined in the Tea Room. Their teas smell heavenly, I wanted to buy them all. 

Once you have your cream, curd, teas: You can invite your girl friends over and recreate this tea party at home for a fraction of the cost!

The petite fours are good but pricey, would skip it next time, save me the $2.50 for spending at the antique shop. All in all, would love to come back for another ladies day out, try out the other sandwiches and teas but mostly to spend time at the antique shop.

*Oh and there were flower vendors that were selling beautiful arrangements for great prices across the street. I believe they were called Bloom Boom. I'll post a pic, they say that they are at different locations around SF.

Comparing this to Crown and Crumpet in Ghirardelli Square, Love Joy is:

Not as "pretty" or "cute" but very real.. feels like I'm in someone's home with an antique setting of mix and matching tea cups, plates, etc.

crumpet.review:
I came here recently with a big group (20pp) for a Bachelorette party. 

Comparing this to Crown and Crumpet in Ghirardelli Square, Love Joy is:
1. Not as "pretty" or "cute" but very real.. feels like I'm in someone's home with an antique setting of mix and matching tea cups, plates, etc. Nothing seems to match, but I really enjoyed it.. they're not trying too hard to impress, it actually made me want to check out the place a little more.

3. way more food - we paid $20~$25 and had some extra sammies to-go!
each person got 8 pieces of sammie (not that I counted how many I've eaten, I know I ate more than that)   That is = 2 whole sammie btw, and you also get a small salad, 1 scone (pretty big), and unlimted tea.
4. Nice friendly staffs.  We were playing games and made so much noise.. basically taking over the entire tea room, sorry folks.

I'd rather come here than Crown and Crumpet, because the price is right and my stomach was satisfied.  

*Keep Calm Carry On*

excerpts: It was a toss up between this place and Crown & Crumpet, but she said this place offered more for your dollar.
crumpet.author: Ashley F.
crumpet.review:
I wrote a brief review elsewhere, and I'm just going to copy/paste it here because I am supremely lazy to do a proper one. Also because I said everything I needed to say, and any elaboration I may be inclined to do will more than likely be odd ramblings.

I had tea ... with my ladybug friend last Friday. It was a toss up between this place and Crown & Crumpet, but she said this place offered more for your dollar. The tea was great (I ended up buying a canister from their retail store across the street), their scones and crumpets should have been illegal, and their chicken apple sandwiches/devonshire cream/lemon curd were to-freaking-die-for.

The place was quirky with mismatched chinaware and fun, vintage décor. As much as I liked it, though, the more compulsive part of my personality begged for less clutter and more sophistication/minimalism. That's not to undermine the atmosphere, though. I loved it, and the service was wonderful.

* What I failed to mention was the type of tea (ceylon). To most people, it might not be something to write home about, but I could have this tea (instead of green) forever and ever. And while I'm skeptical of adding any sugar into my tea, after positive prompting from my friend, I caved and decided a small spoonful of sugar only makes it better. Yum!

Bonus: You get to try on hats if you'd like to, and I'm attesting to other reviews that they rarely let your teapot get more than halfway empty.

excerpts: My friend and I ordered the Queen's tea, which allowed for us to select 2 sandwhiches and came with salad, coleslaw, shortbread biscuit, crumpet, fresh fruit, crumpet, preserves, lemon curd, double devon cream AND a petit fours.
crumpet.author: Hiromi N.
crumpet.review:
"I feel pretty! Oh so pretty! I feel pretty and witty and gay and I pity any girl who isn't me today..."  

Lovejoy's has me channeling my inner MARIA and feeling like dancing on the rooftops, respectfully, of course!  Just enough SHABBY CHIC with cute frilly accents to satisfy the girly-girl heart that beats within me.  Not overly pretentious nor overly saccharin.  One word that remains in my head following my afternoon tea here with a friend:  CHARMING.

In my opinion, securing an actual reservation for afternoon tea was the most difficult part of the whole experience.  It seems that weekend time slots book AT LEAST a week in advance.  Yet,  once we were confirmed everything else was SUBLIME.  By everything else, I mean the service, the ambiance, the food and tea selection.

My friend and I ordered the Queen's tea, which allowed for us to select 2 sandwhiches and came with salad, coleslaw, shortbread biscuit, crumpet, fresh fruit, crumpet, preserves, lemon curd, double devon cream AND a petit fours.  All were scrumptious!!!

Yet, a word of caution: if there are more than 1 in a party, they will charge based on the # of individuals.  This is kind of confusing.  It looks like we were charged $24.95 for the Queen's Tea and $24.00 for every extra person.  It's a bit tricky.

All in all, we spent about $67.30 (incl tax, but not tip).  A hefty price for tea, but so far, this has been my most enjoyable experience.

Parking in the area can be tough.  Public transport runs on Church Street.

excerpts: The Queen's Tea comes with your choice of tea with unlimited refills, choice of 2 sandwiches, cole slaw, green salad, platter of fresh fruit, a scone with preserves and double devon cream, tea biscuit, crumpet with lemon curd and a petite four.
The High Tea is just the same sans the fresh fruit, crumpet and petite four http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=9qzUBqc5axqMSGw-DIrsPQ.
We opted for the Genmai Tea and Black Current Tea.
The crumpet http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=9KKmlGQB8rVk3Sc3ypRWOg looked like a sponge to me but was also good.
crumpet.author: Mona C.
crumpet.review:
[M]ona: 5 Stars
[W]ayne: 4.5 Stars
Average: 4.75 Stars

+ Great Ambiance
+ Excellent Service
+ Nice Tea Selection 
+ Cute Interior and Decor
+ Accepts Credit Cards
+ Good Food!
+ Good Tea!
+ Filling
+ Not a "girly" thing
+ 10% off at Lovejoy's Attic

[M] I took my good friend here for her birthday last year and she liked it very much. So this time, I decided to come here with Wayne and have him enjoy the experience as well. If you think Tea parties are for girls only then you're totally wrong hehe. 

We arrived on a Wednesday afternoon (reservations are recommended especially for the weekend) and there was a table in the center of the tea house waiting just for us. Since Wayne is a pretty big eater, we decided on the Queen's Tea http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=57N_lW3GA1ks-eR5xwMmwA for him and a High Tea http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=fn2qSFZVLENOMjuNJS3JQQ for me. The Queen's Tea comes with your choice of tea with unlimited refills, choice of 2 sandwiches, cole slaw, green salad, platter of fresh fruit, a scone with preserves and double devon cream, tea biscuit, crumpet with lemon curd and a petite four. The High Tea is just the same sans the fresh fruit, crumpet and petite four http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=9qzUBqc5axqMSGw-DIrsPQ. We opted for the Genmai Tea and Black Current Tea. For our sandwich selection, we had the smoked salmon and cream cheese, salmon mousse, mandarin orange and cream cheese, and bay shrimp and mayonnaise.

[W] I thought the tea was pretty good here. I originally chose the Afternoon Darjeeling tea and saw the Genmai Tea written on a blackboard in the back of the restaurant. The hostess was nice enough to help me switch out the tea even though they made a point that they normally don't after they have brewed it. The Genmai http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=pOcaHOwOkJQRQSUJVsx19A was light and ricey. Kinda like the ones from Japanese and Korean restaurants. The sandwiches were pretty good. I especially liked the salmon and cream cheese sandwich as well as the mandarin orange and cream cheese was really refreshing. The crumpet http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/s-ihKanDRDHTD8U49HFA5Q?select=9KKmlGQB8rVk3Sc3ypRWOg looked like a sponge to me but was also good. The scones were really filling.

[M] The Black Current black tea has a nice fruity aroma but doesn't taste as it smells. It was a bit strong and bitter and needed some water to tone down the flavor. My favorite tea selection at Lovejoy's is the China Rose Petal Black Tea and Strawberry Green Tea. The hostess recommended us the Chestnut tea. Perhaps we will try that next time. 

[W] Overall experience was nice. I didn't feel out of place since to my surprise, there were quite a lot of men in there. I always imagined tea parties were for "girly-girls" but Mona totally proved me wrong. We would definitely be back.

excerpts: You get to choose from different tea services, I chose the "Queen's Tea," which gives you a choice of two sandwiches, organic green salad, coleslaw, a scone, and crumpet, preserves, Devon cream, lemon curd, and of course, your tea.
crumpet.author: Courtney S.
crumpet.review:
High Tea is one of my favorite things.  Usually in the late afternoon, it's an opportunity to nosh in place of a traditional dinner.  When the idea came up to have an outing at Lovejoy's I jumped on it.  I've never been to the establishment before but I am always on the lookout.

Lovejoy's is a lovely little tea room that serves some of the best raisin scones with lemon curd I've ever eaten.  You get to choose from different tea services, I chose the "Queen's Tea," which gives you a choice of two sandwiches, organic green salad, coleslaw, a scone, and crumpet, preserves, Devon cream, lemon curd, and of course, your tea.  I chose the Dragon Well green tea.  

The food was delicious, the tea was perfectly steeped, the atmosphere was pleasant, and the service was excellent.  I love Lovejoy's and would definitely return.

excerpts: You get a scone and a crumpet, salad and cole slaw, and this fruit feast, bottomless tea, 8 finger sandwiches and a petit-fors
crumpet.author: Angela H.
crumpet.review:
We had a great time at tea on Friday! Company could not be beat! :D

We all had the Queen's Tea and I'd go with that again. You get a scone and a crumpet, salad and cole slaw, and this fruit feast, bottomless tea, 8 finger sandwiches and a petit-fors [albeit I coulda skipped the slaw, salad and crumpet].

We ordered the: Egg & Onion, Apple-Walnut Chicken, Pear & Stilton, Chicken &  Asparagus, Albacore Tuna & Celery, Cucumber & Cream Cheese, Chutney & Cheese, Roast Beef & Horseradish. I give my favorites vote to Egg & Onion, and the Pear & Stilton. I did not like the chutney and was told to skip the asparagus.

This is my 5th tea this year. I've been to the English Rose in San Carlos twice [lousy service and food poisoning], Teas the Season in San Mateo [tasty & clean, less homey, close to home] and Tea at the Fairmont in San Jose [expensive!! and tiny, but glad we did it once]; by far, Lovejoys was the best.

They had the cutest environment, most plentiful and tastiest food [fresh, too!], personable service, and it certainly was the most economic choice for what was served. I won't hesitate to come back and bring friends - or another hat!

excerpts: Compared to Crown and Crumpet, this place is just as good if not better.
crumpet.author: Liz Q.
crumpet.review:
Compared to Crown and Crumpet, this place is just as good if not better. 

We ordered High Tea for Two:
1) coleslaw: delicious but not too creamy.
2) Egg sandwich: very good and I like how they didn't put too much mayo.
3) smoked salmon with cream cheese and cucumbers with cream cheese: LOVE (there is no way in hell someone can mess that up).
4) Bottomless Dragon tea:  light and fab!

The pastries were very good as well.

I recommend reservations because it gets packed.

excerpts: In contrast to the brightness and cuteness of Crown & Crumpet, Lovejoy's interior looked antique and mismatched and absolutely lovely.
The cups and plates were all unique and pretty.
crumpet.author: Annie Y.
crumpet.review:
In the last few years, I have nurtured a love for afternoon tea. Something about sitting around a wooden table with a lace tablecloth, or antique-style sofa with a few friends and a nice pot of tea really resonates within me. One would think I feel like a pretentious bourgeois snob, and I am not hypocritical enough to deny it; however, just let it be known that being San Franciscan automatically ingrained a bit of elitism in me. That being said, Lovejoy's Tea Room was not the first time I've taken afternoon tea, and it certainly won't be my last.

We came to Lovejoy's for my friend's birthday and hoped that we did not miss our stop while riding the J-line. The exterior did not impress me, but the moment we stepped inside, it was as if we were transported into another world. In contrast to the brightness and cuteness of Crown & Crumpet, Lovejoy's interior looked antique and mismatched and absolutely lovely. The cups and plates were all unique and pretty. Of the three tea rooms I've been to thus far, the interior design of Lovejoy's is my favorite by far. 

Luckily for us, it was a slow Friday afternoon and we were immediately seated, despite our lack of a reservation. Score! In preparation for documenting my friend's birthday, I brought my camera so I ended up obnoxiously taking pictures of the interior. We made our order, of High Tea for four and the Queen's Tea for the birthday girl.

Food was mediocre. Honestly, the best thing about the food they gave us was the dressing for the salad. I got the smoked salmon with cream cheese, and Lovejoy's special, which was chicken and pesto. Both were unimpressive and was much too creamy. The Devon Cream made me feel as if I were eating butter. I've had better scones elsewhere. The strawberry preserves they gave us was definitely not homemade, and reminded me of smuckers (didn't even spring for Bonne Maman!), and the lemon curd was not tart enough.

But the tea was fantastic! I loved the pomegranate green, and the China Rose Petal tea was a perfect sweetness (this is from someone who does not like herbal teas). Those were my favorites of the five we order. The waitress was also really nice.

Usually, I'd give three stars for mediocre food, but the decorum, service, and company made the entire experience much more enjoyable than the food. This is a fantastic place for just a lovely day out.

Bottom-line: you come here for the setting, the company, and the tea; but not the food.

excerpts: I couldn't resist Devonshire cream AND lemon curd on them PLUS buttering the crumpet
(It WAS my birthday.)
Perhaps we should have brought a bottle of bubbly with us - corkage is reasonable.
On the other hand, we were stuffed and loggy with tea.
crumpet.author: Francesca G.
crumpet.review:
Think Alice in Wonderland's or Mary Poppin's tea.  This is a perfect spot for a fun event.  One of us was turning 60, another was turning 65, but the place was full of younger folk, too, evidently celebrating, perhaps engagements.  Lots of eye candy decorates the room - china and linens.

Reservations were no problem (and necessary).  Oddly enough, parking was not a problem.  Once you are there, settle in for a good long time. The staff was wonderful, attentive, accomodating and informative!

The five of us had the Queen's Tea - a feast.  Be sure to tell the staff if there is a birthday in the group so they can put a candle in the petit four (too bad I am not one for almond paste).  I suggest that each guest order a different sandwich filling and then share around the table.  Same with the tea, get different ones and share, being sure to ask for hot water refills.  

Believe everyone about the scones!  I couldn't resist Devonshire cream AND lemon curd on them PLUS buttering the crumpet (It WAS my birthday.)  Perhaps we should have brought a bottle of bubbly with us - corkage is reasonable.  On the other hand, we were stuffed and loggy with tea.  Tea can be quite stimulating - the room rings with conversation.

Sometime that's more fun than a bar crawl, ladies.  BTDTBTT.

excerpts: And having just come from Crown and Crumpet, I can say that I prefer Lovejoys because of the sandwich selections.
crumpet.author: Deanna L.
crumpet.review:
Kind of new to the whole tea thing, I wasn't sure what to expect. I was super excited though, and definitely not disappointed. It definitely has a cozy feel to it, so I wouldn't imagine it would be able to accommodate huge groups. I think the mismatched furniture and silverware adds a nice touch to the atmosphere. 

The sandwiches were really good! We had the high tea for two and were rather full by the end. We got the cucumber sandwich, roast beef with horseradish, salmon with cream cheese and stilton and pear (love!). The warm scones were delicious and the dressing for the salad was lovely. Not the hugest fan of the coleslaw, probably because of mint? in it. I don't know. And having just come from Crown and Crumpet, I can say that I prefer Lovejoys because of the sandwich selections.

excerpts: After all, they are crumpet finger foods.
Although, there was a funny moment when both my cousin and I noticed on our way back from the bathroom that they were just using Safeway Select bread for the sandwiches.
I guess it's what's in it that counts because it was still delicious.
I'm better off staying home and making him multiple regular non crumpet sandwiches.
crumpet.author: Krystal C.
crumpet.review:
I was here for a bachelorette party with 6 girls.  The sandwiches and tea were delicious, there was a huge selection to choose from on the menu.  I've also done the afternoon tea at the Fairmont which was much more frou frou, I felt like I should have worn a big hat just to eat there.  This place, on the other hand, was a much more casual atmosphere.  They had cute knick knack tea related memorabilia around that were really cute.  

As for the food, the sandwiches were delicious and the size was about what I expected.  After all, they are crumpet finger foods.  Although, there was a funny moment when both my cousin and I noticed on our way back from the bathroom that they were just using Safeway Select bread for the sandwiches.  I guess it's what's in it that counts because it was still delicious.  Also, at the end of your tea, they also give you a coupon to use at their cute gift/antique shop across the street. 

My only criticism of this place is they are very stringent with the time.  Our reservations was at 11am, which is when they opened.  We arrived there are 10:45am and were waiting for them to open the doors.  While we were waiting, there was also a baby shower party waiting.  At this point, there was a huge crowd of people outside but even so, they still wouldn't let us come in from the cold to be seated a little early.  Then, at the end, our 2 hour limit was up and as we were chatting, our waitress came and said nicely, "this is your 15 min warning because your 2 hours is coming up soon, thank you."  I was a little taken aback because even though she was very  nice about it, calling it a warning didn't help. 

However, I would come here again, tho never with a guy- he would never get enough to eat.  I'm better off staying home and making him multiple regular non crumpet sandwiches.

excerpts: The warm scone were awesome and the toasted crumpet was pretty good but the lemon curd was super runny and not really that great.
The tea sandwiches were also pretty good.
You can tell they were super fresh.
Their tea sandwich selection was great...
so many tea sandwiches to chose from.
You get your choice of any two to go with your tea.
I liked being able to pick your own sandwiches.
I did not like only getting two choices though.
Usually at other tea places I would get four tea sandwiches (one piece of each) plus savory pastries, so the two tea sandwiches (four pieces of each) and no savory pastries to go with
, it seemed a little redundant after a while.
If I come here again I will be sure to suggest we all get different sandwiches and trade some pieces
so we all get some more variety which would solve the problem... though I was a little disappointed that they didn't already have something like that built into the menu.
They also served salad and coleslaw with the tea.
With the queen's tea I also got a choice of petite four which they had 3 or 4 different flavors or a frosted rice krispy treat.
I chose the rice krispy treat which was good.
It was nice to get the choice.
The tea selection was pretty low... not too much variety.
crumpet.author: Christina P.
crumpet.review:
I came here with a couple friends for tea on a Saturday afternoon. I made reservations in advance which was pretty easy. I called and had to leave a message. They called me back right away and let me know the time I wanted was not available but let me know when they did have an opening. When we came for tea we were a little late because of traffic and trying to find parking (which wasn't too bad) and wasn't given a hard time about coming late which was nice. I had the queen's tea. The warm scone were awesome and the toasted crumpet was pretty good but the lemon curd was super runny and not really that great. The tea sandwiches were also pretty good. You can tell they were super fresh. Their tea sandwich selection was great... so many tea sandwiches to chose from. You get your choice of any two to go with your tea. I liked being able to pick your own sandwiches. I did not like only getting two choices though. Usually at other tea places I would get four tea sandwiches (one piece of each) plus savory pastries, so the two tea sandwiches (four pieces of each) and no savory pastries to go with, it seemed a little redundant after a while. If I come here again I will be sure to suggest we all get different sandwiches and trade some pieces so we all get some more variety which would solve the problem... though I was a little disappointed that they didn't already have something like that built into the menu. They also served salad and coleslaw with the tea. With the queen's tea I also got a choice of petite four which they had 3 or 4 different flavors or a frosted rice krispy treat. I chose the rice krispy treat which was good. It was nice to get the choice. The tea selection was pretty low... not too much variety. They did keep filling up our tea pots though which kept the tea nice and warm and full! 

Speaking of warm though... that place was so warm and stuffy! It was so uncomfortable. I was sweating, trying to enjoy my warm tea, quickly losing my appetite, feeling dirty and sticky from the runny lemon curd with only one smallish paper napkin to try and wipe up all the sticky lemon curd from my fingers while trying to protect my lap from the same fate as my sticky fingers. Bleh! It wasn't even that hot outside... maybe in the mid 70s outside.

The service was alright. Not really the pleasant over the top politeness I have come to expect from tea services. Also, toward the end of tea they came up to us with the check and let us know that there will be another party coming to take our table. This has never happened to me before in all my life. Disappointing because I do like to enjoy my tea service leisurely as it should be had. 

Overall, I was not too impressed with this place. If I do come back it will definitely be a strictly winter/fall tea stop.

excerpts: A little while later came my fresh crumpet.
crumpet.author: Monique H.
crumpet.review:
Went here for the first time today.  My girlfriend from high school was visiting from out of town and we had been talking about having high tea.  After much searching and disappointment that The Four Seasons Hotels and the Ritz-Carlton Hotels have discontinued their tea service, we found this place on Yelp.

We were half an hour late (boyfriends are slow) but lucky one person in our party was only 5 minutes late and saved the table for us.  She said they were very nice and didn't harass her about the rest of her party not showing up.

I had the Queen's Tea with English Breakfast tea and cucumber and turkey sandwiches.  The tea arrived first and after waiting anxiously for it to seep, I poured myself a cup.  It was delicious, but I am not a tea connoisseur.  Then arrived the food, on a three tiered platter.  The top tier was the fresh fruit, next the scone, biscuit, jam, lemon stuff, and the devon cream, the bottom tier had the sandwiches, cole slaw, and greens.

To be frank, when I first looked at it I thought they kind of skimped out on the fruit, but I was stuffed by the end of my meal, so really they are smarter than me!

After having some fruit, I decided to try the scone.  I first tried the devon cream...and that is when I realized that I loved this place!  If I had a lover, forget the whipped cream or chocolate sauce, this is what I'd cover his body with and lick off!!!  I could not get enough of it and I think this was my favorite item here.  Of course the jam and lemon stuff was good too, but I cannot describe my devotion to devon cream now.

The sandwiches were of course delicious and...dainty, delicate?  FUN!  I am not a super girlie girl.  My friend and I decided to put dresses on for the special occasion and I felt like a streetwalker even though my dress is conservative, but that is how rarely I wear things that don't have legs.  But this place played into my feminine side without me feeling awkward about it.  So yes, it's frilly and kitsch, but it works for this place.

A little while later came my fresh crumpet.  We decided crumpets are a pancake-english muffin hybrid, a puffin. Delicious, but I just wanted to get back to my scone and devon cream to be honest.

Lastly when we were done, we had our petite fours.  Which apparently I didn't really experience because I got the dark chocolate truffle with dried apricot.  But it was so cute and I love dark chocolate.  Petite fours are candy-sized, individually glazed pieces of cake. (My friend went to culinary school)

I completely want to return, but will probably only get the High Tea or even just the Light Tea next time.  The Queen's Tea was fantastic for the first time, so you get the entire experience and learn what you like.  But I personally didn't really like the cole slaw (I'm too American and eating it made me want ribs or something) and I was too full to even consider wasting space on a salad!

So if you go, invite me?

excerpts: The crumpets were also quite tasty but the lemon curd really made the crumpet amazing.
crumpet.author: Cara D.
crumpet.review:
This is probably one of the most eclectic places I have been to! With its mismatched everything and most adorable decorations, Lovejoy's is a perfect place for any occasion, even if its just a lunch on a regular Saturday.

I was treated to a Queens tea here and boy did I feel like a Queen.  Two sandwiches for each person, meaning I got to try 4!  The special of the turkey and cranberry was so delicious and my favorite out of all the ones I tried.  And the scones, the scones were just so yummy.  They were not dry like many scones you taste, but warm (even after they had been sitting on our table for a while) and much more moist than many others.  Plus the strawberry jam made the scone even better!  The crumpets were also quite tasty but the lemon curd really made the crumpet amazing.  Finally the petite fours (or however you spell them) just topped it off!

The whole experience was delightful.  The staff was more than helpful, nice and I just really enjoyed the whole experience!

excerpts: Then we strolled around the neighborhood to walk off some crumpet.
It was a lovely time and I highly recommend it.
crumpet.author: Alissa S.
crumpet.review:
Queen for a Day, what more do you need?

The planets aligned and five of us had two free hours to catch up on the same day at the same time, so I booked a reservation for tea. From the moment we arrived, we had so much fun! We had two waitresses , the table said, "reserved for queens", they explained the teas like they were wines, and the food was excellent. The scones were round, soft, and warm, the real deal. The double Devonshire cream was excellent, the lemon curd fresh, and the strawberry jam not too sweet. My Queen's tea came with all of the above, my own pot of tea, four sandwiches (I had roast beef and chicken salad, yum) and a salad and coleslaw and cookies and a petit four and crumpets. There was plenty of food, we boxed up some to go! Then we strolled around the neighborhood to walk off some crumpet. It was a lovely time and I highly recommend it.

excerpts: I better mention now that the more horrid flaw regarding money (which I checked out just recently) is that each person must spend a little under $10 meaning that for example, if you're just by yourself, you can't just get a crumpet and milk and be good to go because you just spent $7.37 only before the tip.
crumpet.author: Don U.
crumpet.review:
Honestly, I wanted to give Lovejoy's Tea Room a higher score.  I mean, it's a British tea place.  You don't find this sort of place in the Bay Area. (Yes, you see plenty of milk tea and Thai tea places, but not British tea places.) It's that the place has a good amount of glaring flaws.  It has 3 stars, but the place is really A-OK indeed.  Side note: one of my sisters brought my siblings and I over to this place for her birthday, my only visit to this place.

As I mentioned in the last paragraph, this is a British tea place.  Obviously, the place has the British look when you go inside.  Oh and of course, this is definitely a place ladies generally should feel at ease.

What was good about the place?  I like the surroundings.  The server we had was wonderful.  The staff members as a whole were wonderful I should say.  Of course, the tea would be good. (This is a tea place after all.) You are given your milk and sugar.  Oh and it is awesome that they carry jade tea, but even if your not much of a tea person, there are other drinks to choose from like coffee and hot chocolate. (Side note: for tea and coffee, I need milk and sugar, but I never put either in jade tea.)

Now, I bring out the flaws.  The place is pricey, but it's San Francisco, and adding on, I'll mention a more horrid flaw regarding money in a bit.  I know that this a tea place, but the food was lackluster.  Outside of the scones, a good amount of the food was mediocre at best.  The place is so small, I wonder how someone like Mr. Corey Maggette would manage to feel comfortable without a chair.  Parking is such a bother, but again, it's San Francisco.  I better mention now that the more horrid flaw regarding money (which I checked out just recently) is that each person must spend a little under $10 meaning that for example, if you're just by yourself, you can't just get a crumpet and milk and be good to go because you just spent $7.37 only before the tip.  Even if you add the tip, you're still under the minimum, as that's only $8.48.

I need to get a couple of notes out of the way.  Obviously, if you plan on coming here, make a reservation ahead of time.  Also, you can purchase the cups and other items.  Just go to the store across the street.

I love the atmosphere.  I love the service we received.  I don't love the lackluster food and the money issues.  Lovejoy's is a place I don't mind going to again for tea with crumpets and biscuits.  I just hope the flaws I mentioned are fixed up.

+:  The service is terrific and Lovejoy's Tea Room gets originality points for being a British tea place, a type of place you will not see often in the Bay Area or probably out west for that matter.

-:  The food is seriously lackluster overall and you figure that you get a little more out of each dollar spent.

excerpts: very interesting food especially like the tea, crumpet and scones with devon cream.
the petite four are cute but too sweet even for me.
ill bring my aunts here next time and plan to try thei lemon curd, salmon sandwich, etc :).
ohh and weedays are good!
no need to wait and no crowd!
crumpet.author: Elc C.
crumpet.review: i shared a querns tea with houseblend tea with my mom.  very interesting food especially like the tea, crumpet and scones with devon cream.  the petite four are cute but too sweet even for me.  ill bring my aunts here next time and plan to try thei lemon curd, salmon sandwich, etc :). ohh and weedays are good!  no need to wait and no crowd!

excerpts: I literally moaned when I put the crumpet topped with Devonshire cream in my mouth.
It just melted...
I loved that combination so much, that I went to their retail store across the street to purchase a jar.
As far as teas, they offer a wide selection...
crumpet.author: Kat M.
crumpet.review:
This quaint and charming Tea room is very Victorianesque. Everything -- from the furniture to the ensembles of the waitresses, is Victorian. The place has an old feel to it. It's extremely girly, so I wouldn't recommend bringing the boys here. Make a reservation for the girls. This would be an awesome "girls day out" place to visit.

I will admit, at first glance, I didn't believe anything on the menu would fill me up. However, each item was so rich with fresh flavor and I was actually stuffed by our meal's end. A downfall -- the prices. I didn't expect tea and sandwiches to be that expensive. The way I see it is, I paid for the experience of trying something new in a great environment, where they definitely pay attention to detail and where high attentive and personable.

If it's just you and another person, order the High Tea for Two. You get to choose several different sandwiches, spring greens, scones, shortbread, biscuits, crumpets, and spreads. I loved the cucumber and cream cheese and apple walnut salad. I literally moaned when I put the crumpet topped with Devonshire cream in my mouth. It just melted...I loved that combination so much, that I went to their retail store across the street to purchase a jar. As far as teas, they offer a wide selection...I would try one from each category.

In short, try it on a Saturday or Sunday morning with girlfriends!

excerpts: Lovejoy's certainly doesn't need another review, but I've just got to show my love - especially since I'm going to try Crown & Crumpet tomorrow
crumpet.author: Amy D.
crumpet.review:
Lovejoy's certainly doesn't need another review, but I've just got to show my love - especially since I'm going to try Crown & Crumpet tomorrow & I'm feeling a little guilty.

The food, the service, the mismatched dinnerware & the cozy feeling I always get are all of the same reasons I return again & again. 

This is the perfect tea house for special occasions like birthdays, showers, or to just celebrate life alone when you feel like treating yourself to a wonderful treat.

I've never brought any Lovejoy's virgin here that didn't RAVE about it & become an instant fan only to return time & time on her own or with me (when I'm lucky) over & over.

Rain or shine, Lovejoy's is perfect ANY time.

excerpts: There are also extra little things that come with the Queen's tea like a crumpet - it was pretty bland, but i'm assuming that's just what it tastes like - and a petit four at the end.
I think i had so much tea that I could barely eat the petit four.
When i went home i devoured my leftover sandwiches and the rest of the shepherd's pie - and total after splitting with my friend was only around 20 dollars!
Would definitely recommend and come again.
A nice place for bunch or a small get together with girlfriends!
crumpet.author: Sophia D.
crumpet.review: Very fun!  I came here with a girlfriend and we had a really good time.  We ordered one Queen's tea and one shepherd's pie and we had food leftover.  We got the black tea with lavender which was really good, the asparagus sandwich, and the lox sandwich.  The scone was delicious with the jams and butter, and the sandwiches were good too!  I liked how it came with plenty of salad - so you don't need to order an extra salad - and the little fruit on top was tasty!  There are also extra little things that come with the Queen's tea like a crumpet - it was pretty bland, but i'm assuming that's just what it tastes like - and a petit four at the end.  I think i had so much tea that I could barely eat the petit four.  When i went home i devoured my leftover sandwiches and the rest of the shepherd's pie - and total after splitting with my friend was only around 20 dollars!  Would definitely recommend and come again.  A nice place for bunch or a small get together with girlfriends!

excerpts: I don't think I would go there again soon - for two of us, we spent 55 dollars and we had tea, two small sandwiches, a scone, some mixed greens (the kind that you would buy at Safeway in a plastic bin), some coleslaw, and a crumpet.
For our large group of eight, we spent $225 altogether.
For the money spent, even though yes the ingredients overall were nice, it just is a very extravagant lunch where you leave feeling waterlogged on tea but not necessarily full full.
Not that you have to feel like you should unbutton your pants and roll out the door, it just feels like a lot of money for tea and white bread sandwiches.
crumpet.author: P B.
crumpet.review:
Overall, It's a very nice place, great decorations. We had a large group and were able to sit there as long as we wanted. Serving staff was really nice to us.

I don't think I would go there again soon - for two of us, we spent 55 dollars and we had tea, two small sandwiches, a scone, some mixed greens (the kind that you would buy at Safeway in a plastic bin), some coleslaw, and a crumpet. For our large group of eight, we spent $225 altogether. For the money spent, even though yes the ingredients overall were nice, it just is a very extravagant lunch where you leave feeling waterlogged on tea but not necessarily full full. Not that you have to feel like you should unbutton your pants and roll out the door, it just feels like a lot of money for tea and white bread sandwiches. But if you go there feeling hungry, you need to drop 30-35 to leave feeling satisfied - otherwise, you will find yourself eating like a whole tub of jam, butter, and cream.

However, the things I did like were the devon double cream and the lemon curd. The coleslaw was good - they had caraway seeds in them - not too sweet.

Again, for the money, we got as much tea as we wanted, but we each received a knife, spoon, and fork, with no serving utensils for anything. They put the greens and the coleslaw (plus the sandwiches, etc) on these big tier trays but they don't have serving utensils. So you just use your fingers or try to use your one spoon that you use to stir your tea to scoop greens onto your plate. It just ended up a bit germy and messy. I was using my knife I had just slathered with cream and jam, etc and then had to use it as a serving utensil for the coleslaw, etc. They didn't refresh plates, so if you had used your one small plate to eat salad, you also had to use it to serve your sweet stuff and it all got mixed together. By the end, it was pretty gross.

Also, they use these thin textured square napkins (the kind we grew up on when we had people over) for their hand towels in the bathroom. They don't work so well...get bits of paper falling off - almost like drying your hands with toilet paper. But that's being a little picky.

excerpts: I had to Queens Tea which is $24.95 per person and comes with two sandwiches of your choice (I had artichoke hummus and pear with stilton), coleslaw, greens, scones, devon cream, preserves, crumpet, lemon curd, fruit, petit four, and a biscuit and of course your choice of tea.
It was 5 years ago and I still think about it and need to return.
Its not an everyday thing, of course.
But it is a wonderful luxury every once in a while.

excerpts: The crumpet came a little later and I was pleasantly surprised.
I had never tried one, and I wanted another as soon as I tasted it.
crumpet.author: Alyssa d.
crumpet.review: Went here for my birthday lunch, a gift to me from my sister.  I saw this place on "Check Bay Area Please" and decided to give it a try.  I was not disappointed. We got the Queen's tea and I was so surprised at the selections.  Bottomless pot of English Breakfast Tea.  I had the stilton and pear and the salmon and cream cheese.  Delish.  The crumpet came a little later and I was pleasantly surprised.  I had never tried one, and I wanted another as soon as I tasted it.  I have never been a fan of scones, but this is also the first time I had a hot scone.  It was wonderful.  Great experience, my first time at a tea house.  I will be back!

excerpts: My friends and I came across this place on yelp and decided to try it because it has better reviews than other places like Crown & Crumpet.
crumpet.author: Roland R.
crumpet.review:
My friends and I came across this place on yelp and decided to try it because it has better reviews than other places like Crown & Crumpet.

Note that their last seating is at 4.30-5pm.

The place was very well decorated. There were antique sofas and mirrors. They had cute little trinkets and even a red telephone booth display! It had a vintage feel to it.
The tea sets and plates were also beautiful, but strangely, they were mismatched. Hmmm
Anyway, it's still a good place for snacks, to hang out and relax.

My friends and I shared the Queen's tea (complete with scones, crumpets, salad, sandwiches and lots more) and I think it was enough for 2 people. We ended up paying $15 each.

I like it that they had a great selection of teas and sandwiches (check out the menu on their website). I tried the peach and china rose tea and for sandwiches, smoked salmon and pear & Stilton.  The teas were very fragrant and the sandwiches were pretty good even though they were so small. I had scones with raisins and strawberry preserves. It was heavenly!

The people who worked there were very welcoming, exceptionally patient and friendly. I really enjoyed the experience and I really recommend Lovejoy's!

excerpts: Also, when you choose your petits fours at the end of your tea ritual, I would suggest avoiding the salted caramel truffle unless you like your truffle EXTREMELY salty.
petits fours.author: Kim D.
petits fours.review:
I came here for my sister's baby sprinkle in a party of ~ 8. It was my first time experiencing high tea, and I didn't expect anything great; I mean, it's just tea and some overpriced biscuits. How great can it be, right?

Well, I found out that it's pretty darn great! First off, everything was adorable, from the mismatched plates and saucers to the homey, antiquey decorations around the tea room. It reminds me of Alice in Wonderland, just a bit! The service is also wonderful. She always came around to keep our tea pots full and to make sure we were doing okay. 

The menu is extensive - you're definitely not limited in food, as there's salad, fruit, crumpets, scones, sandwiches, and other pastries. I ordered the Queen's tea with a pomegranate black tea and shared it with my cousin. It's seriously a lot of food! My favorites were the buttery, delicate scones, crumpets, and the smoked salmon and cream cheese sandwiches. They were heavenly when paired with the tea. I prefer plain unsweetened tea, but they do provide sugar and milk for you to add as you prefer it. Also, when you choose your petits fours at the end of your tea ritual, I would suggest avoiding the salted caramel truffle unless you like your truffle EXTREMELY salty. Everything else seemed fine, though.

Overall, I'd definitely come back when I'm in SF. Seeing as how brunch has become pretty basic (but I'm still a huge brunch fanatic - does that make me basic?), I say skip the eggs benedicts and mimosas and have a tea party date with your girlfriends at Lovejoy's instead!

excerpts: I have had both the High Tea ($17.95) and the Queen's Tea ($24.95), and I do think that unless you love crumpets (I don't) and petits fours (I do, but I can live without them after consuming a whole tea service), it's not worth the extra $7 for the Queen's Tea.
The High Tea is such a good bargain - so much food for under $20 - that it almost moots the point of the Queen's Tea, in my mind.
petits fours.author: Lis B.
petits fours.review:
I absolutely adore Lovejoy's.  It is the quintessetial tea room.  Girly, dainty, chintzy, and oh-so-English, it's a definite winner.

Gentlemen:  enter at your own risk.

I have had both the High Tea ($17.95) and the Queen's Tea ($24.95), and I do think that unless you love crumpets (I don't) and petits fours (I do, but I can live without them after consuming a whole tea service), it's not worth the extra $7 for the Queen's Tea.  The High Tea is such a good bargain - so much food for under $20 - that it almost moots the point of the Queen's Tea, in my mind.

With both teas, you get your choice of tea sandwiches (I love the pear/blue cheese and the apple/cream cheese), tea (they're all good!), warm scone (with lemon curd, jam and clotted cream), coleslaw, spring salad (with mandarin oranges) and shortbread cookie.  The Queen's tea adds a crumpet, a petit four, and a lot of fresh fruit.  

All of the tea cups and saucers are mismatched, making it all completely adorable.  It's all for sale, too.  Just ask (they also have a shop with everything for sale across the street).  

I like sitting near the front, near one of the windows.  It's especially nice if you can get a seat on the banquette and tuck yourself in.  The place is always packed, and it's good to be able to observe the fray, rather than be a part of it.  Speaking of packed, reservations are a necessity.

The waitstaff is always friendly and helpful, although they sometimes look a bit beleaguered.

And the best part about coming here?  In addition to the delicious tidbits I hear from my friends over tea, I always end up hearing little snippets of other people's conversations (hey, the place *is* small), and I've learned more about complete strangers than I ever wanted to know.  Something about the tea must make them open up and spill all their secrets!!

excerpts: And the petits fours (mmm, marzipan!).
petits fours.author: mary r.
petits fours.review:
My mom and her side of the family are English, so I kind of know my way around an English tea.  And when I say tea, I mean tea and the food that goes with it.

Lovejoy's has an unsurpassed tea menu...and again, I'm talking about the food.  Their sandwiches are cute, little, de-crusted  combos of cream cheese & cucumber, cheese & tomato, roast beef & horseradish, ham & spicy mustard, cheese & chutney and on and on and on.  There is no skimping on that sandwich menu, believe me.  They serve Taylor's tea, among other choices, so that's pretty cool....but it'd be even cooler if they carried Sainsbury's Red Label!

And then there's the scones.  And the chestnut tea.  And the shortbread.  And the sausage rolls (not as good as my mom makes 'em, but still good enough to scare away any avid dieters).  And the petits fours (mmm, marzipan!).  And the pasties (savory pies, not nipple hiders).  YES.  They have delicious, savory pies here!  Yum.  Although, I'm sure a lot more men would come here if the pasties advertised were of the tittie-bar variety.  And yes, I just used "tittie-bar" while reviewing a tea room.

Which brings me to my next point:  this place has a lovely atmosphere for say, a lunch with the ladies, or a baby shower or just plain high tea.  But it can be a bit precious with all the crazy estrogen and flowered what-nots floating around.  Every time I come here, there is maybe one (bored or forced-to-look-happy) man for every 8 women sitting in the place.  And there are doilies.  Not like that's any different from my mom's house.  I'm just warning the not-so-feminine and the ladylike-lacking so you're not surprised if you get the evil eye for saying something along the lines of  "HOLY FUCKING SHIT!!!  THIS PLACE IS RAD!"

excerpts: The dining portions were more than generous - hearty, dainty tea sandwiches on a bed of mixed greens w/walnuts and mandarins and balsamic dijon vinaigrette, fresh fruits, warm scones, shortbread tea biscuits, warm crumpets, lemon curd, strawberry preserves and petits fours!
Strawberries, blueberries, pineapples, scones - you name it
, I spread cream on it.
petits fours.author: Olma M.
petits fours.review:
Absolutely splendid, lovely, quaint and all-around wonderful tea room.  Attended a birthday tea party here and just loved it.  We were a party of 15 on a bustling sunny Saturday afternoon/evening (4-6 p.m.).

The dining portions were more than generous - hearty, dainty tea sandwiches on a bed of mixed greens w/walnuts and mandarins and balsamic dijon vinaigrette, fresh fruits, warm scones, shortbread tea biscuits, warm crumpets, lemon curd, strawberry preserves and petits fours!  

Oh, and step away from the Double Devon cream, because seriously, as my friend Sarah says, "EVERYTHING is better with cream." And at this place, you may as well take it in intravenously.  Strawberries, blueberries, pineapples, scones - you name it, I spread cream on it.  And yes, they sell this stuff, too - don't even bother looking at the nutritional value (I use the word "value" lightly).

The tea service was prompt and lovely and everything was described to us as they were served.  We had a relatively spacious layout in the back of the bustling tearoom, but it all felt very cozy.

Customer service was extremely personable, professional and warm.  The minute I walked in/out, I was making making a mental list of others with whom I would love to experience Lovejoy's again.  Very old school, English tea vibe with a quaint "attic" just across the street where they sell many of their wares and teas.

I think this statement from their website sums it up rather well: "...our tea room reflects the diversity of San Francisco, blending together the traditions of tea service with an eclectic, quirky and playful spirit."

excerpts: When the woman served us Petits Fours at the end of our meal, she picked the dessert up w/ the tongs and put it on my dirty lunch plate.
Oh, and the Petits Fours were warm.
-PASTRIES.
I've had meatpies overseas, and I really did not enjoy the meatpie here.
I ordered the Curried Chicken, and it was definitely too spicy to be enjoying with tea.
The pastry shell was not flaky and was quite soggy.
It reminded me of one of those microwave pastry deals, but worse.
-AMBIENCE.
The set-up was very cute; however, it did need some tidying up.
Our tablecloth was stained with food and the place seemed like it needed some dusting.
The area that had tea cups, teas, and collectibles for sale was a bit disorganized.
This area drastically needed some cleaning up.
petits fours.author: Carrie A.
petits fours.review:
I went to Lovejoy's for the first time after reading the rave reviews here on Yelp. I usually go to Tranquitea in Pacifica and have experienced a NZ teatime. My thoughts:

Pros:
-TEA SANDWICHES & SCONES. Lovejoy's has an excellent assortment of tea sandwiches. You get to choose from 16 delectable little sandwiches, of which I enjoyed the Chicken-Apple-Walnut and the Chicken & Asparagus. High Tea for Two is an awesome deal.

Cons:
-LACK OF GENUINE CUSTOMER SERVICE. My mom went in to get a table while I found parking. Even though they had four women working, I wasn't greeted at the door and we were only asked how our meal was right at the beginning (when we barely took bites of our food). They topped of my tea without asking if I wanted it topped off (my idea of being wasteful). When the woman served us Petits Fours at the end of our meal, she picked the dessert up w/ the tongs and put it on my dirty lunch plate. Oh, and the Petits Fours were warm.
-PASTRIES. I've had meatpies overseas, and I really did not enjoy the meatpie here. I ordered the Curried Chicken, and it was definitely too spicy to be enjoying with tea. The pastry shell was not flaky and was quite soggy. It reminded me of one of those microwave pastry deals, but worse.
-AMBIENCE. The set-up was very cute; however, it did need some tidying up. Our tablecloth was stained with food and the place seemed like it needed some dusting. The area that had tea cups, teas, and collectibles for sale was a bit disorganized. This area drastically needed some cleaning up. Although some might appreciated the mismatched tea sets, I did not.

Although Lovejoy's has a nice assortment of teas, it wasn't anything that you wouldn't find at any other tea room.

Overall, Lovejoy's was not the pleasant little tea room that I envisioned it to be. I didn't feel like I was truly having High Tea and felt more like I was eating in a San Francisco diner.

DON'T BOTHER GOING HERE.

My recommendation: Tranquilitea in Pacifica. Parking is easy and I guarantee you'll have a heavenly High Tea experience :)

excerpts: My mom ordered the Queen's Tea Service and I ordered the Cream Tea.
We chose the White Peach and Forest Berry tea.
cream tea.author: Merisenda A.
cream tea.review:
This tea room is absolutely adorable. I took my mom here to celebrate her birthday and she loved it.

It's a very eclectic and charming place, various old timey photos adorn the walls. I didn't get any pictures of it, but there's also a chandelier made out of tea cups and a welcome mat made from broken tea cup pieces. 

I like that they have various levels/price points for the tea service. You can also order things a la carte, or a plate. So even if you are on a budget, you can enjoy yourself provided you spend the minimum 11.95 per person. 

There's no shortage of options and the people working there understand - they give you ample time to decide on what you want.

My mom ordered the Queen's Tea Service and I ordered the Cream Tea. We chose the White Peach and Forest Berry tea. Both were really good, though I preferred the sweeter Forest Berry tea.

We came on a Wednesday at 11 am and there was already a large crowd. Luckily we made reservations in advance. I highly recommend making reservations.

The staff was very nice. They even brought out a mini dessert and candle for my mom, which was appreciated. 

This is a great spot for a birthday celebration or brunch, or even a date. When you're done, you can go to Lovejoy's attic across the street and visit their tea cellar.

excerpts: We had a lovely tea here today, ordered the cream tea and the scones were AMAZING!
A relaxed spot, whether you're famished or just want some scones and a bottomless pot of your favorite tea!
We will definitely be back for more!

excerpts: Sub-par cream tea
I feel I must explain what Cream Tea is before I review what I was served.
A cream tea doesn't mean tea which is creamy.
A cream tea is a scone served with clotted cream, optionally (though usually) also jam, and a pot of tea.
It is a kind of set piece.
Clotted cream is a kind of delicious creamy thing about halfway between the most delicate butter you've ever had and whipped cream.
It is, not too put too fine a point on it, the very heart of cream tea.
You want a generous amount of it.
I know all this from having had a great deal of cream tea in England in a variety of tea places.
I ordered cream tea, which came with two scones, about a scant tablespoon of clotted cream, a little bit of jam, and some fresh fruit.
A tablespoon of clotted cream is not enough for one scone, never mind for two.
There should have been at least three times that much clotted cream.
I am not exaggerating or being facetious.
You want to be able to spread a thick amount of clotted cream and then have enough left to lick out of the container like a barbarian, if you can get away with it.

I understand that they are importing clotted cream in tiny jars from the UK at great expense, but considering how much the whole cream tea costs, I think they could afford to be more generous with the stuff.
I'd love for nothing more than to be able to pay slightly too much money for a very good cream tea without flying all the way to England.
cream tea.author: AK K.
cream tea.review:
Sub-par cream tea, I'm afraid. 

Considering how cute the place looks, and how busy, and how good the reviews are, I was expecting something wonderful and invited an out-of-town guest for an afternoon tea. We walked in on a weekday afternoon and were immediately seated. It wasn't busy at all. As everyone says it's quite another matter on weekends. The service was perfectly fine. The food and the tea were sub-par.

I feel I must explain what Cream Tea is before I review what I was served.  A cream tea doesn't mean tea which is creamy. A cream tea is a scone served with clotted cream, optionally (though usually) also jam, and a pot of tea. It is a kind of set piece. Clotted cream is a kind of delicious creamy thing about halfway between the most delicate butter you've ever had and whipped cream. It is, not too put too fine a point on it, the very heart of cream tea. You want a generous amount of it. I know all this from having had a great deal of cream tea in England in a variety of tea places. 

I ordered cream tea, which came with two scones, about a scant tablespoon of clotted cream, a little bit of jam, and some fresh fruit. A tablespoon of clotted cream is not enough for one scone, never mind for two. There should have been at least three times that much clotted cream. I am not exaggerating or being facetious. You want to be able to spread a thick amount of clotted cream and then have enough left to lick out of the container like a barbarian, if you can get away with it. I understand that they are importing clotted cream in tiny jars from the UK at great expense, but considering how much the whole cream tea costs, I think they could afford to be more generous with the stuff. It's also possible to make your own clotted cream from scratch, and the only problem is you have to make rather a lot of it at once which shouldn't be such an issue for a shop that specializes in tea. 

Inexplicably, the scones were heated up. I realize it says that on the menu and perhaps I ought not to have been surprised. But I was surprised because scones should not be warmed up. They should be fresh, but not warm and certainly not re-warmed. Rewarming scones is just not done. I don't know how else to put that. It's incorrect. Aside from it being not done, it's also a bad idea because it will melt your delicious clotted cream and ruin its texture and coolness. It also can't be good for the texture of the scones. 

These were raisin scones, which in my experience are sometimes a bit more solid rather than crumbly, and maybe if they had not been re-heated they would have been on the far end of the acceptable range of scone textures. They were not the right texture. They utterly lacked any crumbliness. Sure, if you're used to Starbucks scones, you might be impressed. But if you are expecting an English style scone, these are not that. They are incorrect.

The jam was fine, though still a little bit less than I would really expect.

To summarize, there was not enough clotted cream and the scones were wrong.

Now let us move on to the tea. I ordered the house blend black tea, and it was a very good full-bodied tea. Milk was provided, as it should be. It was loose-leaf and came in a teapot. You had to strain it with a little strainer when pouring because the leaves are put directly in the teapot. Which is OK and I can't say it's not correct, lots of English people do it that way.

The tea was good for the first cup. Because there was no way to take out the tea leaves, it inevitably became over-brewed for subsequent cups. When I got very close to the bottom of the teapot, the waitress came by to "warm up" the pot to make good on the promise of bottomless tea. I can't be 100% sure about what happened next. Based on the flavor of the tea it seems like the old tea leaves were not replaced and either more hot water was added or more hot water with some more leaves. Anyway it was bitter and not very good a that point. The whole tea part of the experience could be improved by putting the looseleaf tea in a brewing basket (which is not heretical in any way and lots of English tea houses do it, and it's not like authenticity appears to be a concern at this teahouse). 

Everything that went wrong could be fixed with a little bit of effort and care. That's part of why I'm writing this review. I'd love for nothing more than to be able to pay slightly too much money for a very good cream tea without flying all the way to England.

Anyway, I'm sure lots of people will continue to have a nice time playing dress-up and doing England cosplay at this highly atmospheric cute little joint. Heck, maybe the sandwiches are good.

excerpts: I ordered a Cream Tea, a Tea pot and scones, to my delight I also got some fresh fruit with that.
cream tea.author: Tabitha D.
cream tea.review:
This was a lovely way to spend a Sunday afternoon.
I made it in just before the kitchen closed for the day.

I had finished up at Dolores park and wanted to check out something I had bookmarked that was near. 

I am so happy it was here.

I ordered a Cream Tea, a Tea pot and scones, to my delight I also got some fresh fruit with that.

The pot itself was much larger then i am used to receiving at these types of establishments. 
The decorations are adorable and the staff was attentive.
The scone was delicious, my only down side was the scone comes with devon cream and jam, which is good and all but my preferred is lemon curd with.

Lighting is good, not to cramped.
If i come again by myself I will for sure be bringing a good book. It is a great place to sit and read and enjoy your pot of tea. 

Price isn't awful either :D

excerpts: Two of us ordered the Queen's Tea, while everyone else got the cream tea.
The two Queen's teas were put on one double layered tray, which might not have been a problem, but we were not sitting at the same end of the table.
So I never got any greens, or lemon curd, or
what not.

One of the other ladies gave me her cream tea platter and helped me grab my tea sandwiches from the main tray, but that table was way too cluttered with the different pots and such to make passing that multi level tray back and forth.
So it stayed where the waitress had put it, at the other end of the table out of reach.
cream tea.author: Sandra P.
cream tea.review:
Almost five stars.  Almost.  I just attended a party here for a friend's wedding.  The food was great, though I believe the waitress hates her job.  She almost never smiled, and the couple of times she did, it was like she was remembering that she was supposed to, so it was a grimace that lasted a quick second.  

The food, as I said, was great, but here is where they messed up.  Two of us ordered the Queen's Tea, while everyone else got the cream tea. excerpts: Their menu features ala carte items (including pasties ($9.95), shepherd's pie ($10.95), and quiche ($10.95)) and an assortment of combinations, ranging from the "Cream Tea" ($14.95) which comes with scones, fruit, and a bottomless pot o' tea to the "Queen's Tea" ($26.95) which comes with two types of finger sandwiches, a coleslaw type salad, a green salad, scones, crumpets, fruit, petit fours, shortbread tea biscuits, and, of course, a bottomless pot o' tea.
This came with 10 different types of finger sandwiches, 5 different pots of tea, a green salad, coleslaw, scones, and shortbread cookies.
They have many different finger sandwiches to choose from.
My favorites were the smoked salmon and cream cheese, the special chicken and pesto, and the pear and stilton (blue cheese).
They also have an assortment of teas.
We tried the vanilla lavender, a green tea, the spiced citrus, and the teahouse blend.
Our favorite was the Vanilla Lavender so definitely try that one when you go
cream tea.author: Eileen E.
cream tea.review:
The perfect venue for a girly birthday, bridal shower, baby shower, mother's day, or just a cozy hangout with friends. :) For my 26th birthday, I wanted to celebrate with my friends and do something a little bit different than just a fun lunch or dinner. I also wanted to do something that would give us a chance to catch up and chat :). Lovejoy's Tea Room was absolutely perfect for this.  

I made my reservation 2-3 weeks in advance and they were able to seat 7 of us no sweat. We had a big round table near the window with lots of comfy pillows. I think the term "Shabby Chic" was invented to describe the quirky, frilly, cozy decor in this lil tea shop! A sign reading "Reserved for the Queens" was sitting on the table when we arrived. *Does the Queen of England Wave.*

Their menu features ala carte items (including pasties ($9.95), shepherd's pie ($10.95), and quiche ($10.95)) and an assortment of combinations, ranging from the "Cream Tea" ($14.95) which comes with scones, fruit, and a bottomless pot o' tea to the "Queen's Tea" ($26.95) which comes with two types of finger sandwiches, a coleslaw type salad, a green salad, scones, crumpets, fruit, petit fours, shortbread tea biscuits, and, of course, a bottomless pot o' tea.

My friends and I split 5 High Tea's ($19.95) among the 7 of us (see picture for the tower o' treats!). This came with 10 different types of finger sandwiches, 5 different pots of tea, a green salad, coleslaw, scones, and shortbread cookies. They have many different finger sandwiches to choose from. My favorites were the smoked salmon and cream cheese, the special chicken and pesto, and the pear and stilton (blue cheese). They also have an assortment of teas. We tried the vanilla lavender, a green tea, the spiced citrus, and the teahouse blend. Our favorite was the Vanilla Lavender so definitely try that one when you go :).

Thank you so much Lovejoy's for such an adorable, fun, and laidback way to spend my special day with friends!

cream tea.review:
Oh how I love tea and scones.

I made a reservation for five at 1:30 p.m. about two days in advance; two arrived on time, and like proper ladies, the rest of us arrived around 15-20 minutes late. Lovejoy's is really the spitting image of grandma's place, only blown up and with more tables.

Our server was dressed to impress in an old school peasant dress and greeted us with a warm smile. The menus were just printed on paper, but whatever, we were sitting on floral couches and little chairs for chrissakes. Paper menus are perfect.

What we ordered: high tea for two ($34), cream tea ($12.95), and savory tea ($13.95). Each order came with a pot of unlimited tea, which was amazing. The tea cups, pot, plates and whatnot were impossibly fitting; matching tea sets with some mismatched but homey utensils. A couple tea stains here and there, but there's no complaining from me! 

I had the Dragon Well tea (green tea), but I also tried their Yorkshire Gold (black), China Rose Petal (black flavored - it's sweet!) and Darjeeling (black). They basically give you your pots of hot water and the leaves, and instruct you briefly on what to do, aka steeping it for a minute. Oh, and of course there's milk and sugar on the table.

Oh gosh, such good tea! The China Rose Petal turned out to be my favorite of the day, and don't even get me started on the scones with lemon curd and devon cream.... An absolute must try.

The sandwiches were light, cute, and oh-so yummy. We decided to get the cucumber and cream cheese (I don't really recommend it... You can make it yourself, but it's cute...) and their daily special, some sort of curry-like sandwich - which blew my mind. I wish I knew what the name of it was now. 
If you eat a lot, perhaps you should get your own order of sandwiches. 

The store's right across the street, and I've already promptly bought a jar of their lemon curd. 

Keep in mind:
 It's $1 to share your tea.
And calling in to reserve seats never hurt anyone.

excerpts: I got the cream tea with a choice of tea that I cannot exactly remember right now because there's such a huge selection of teas.
I wanted to try all of them!
Okay, first off, I loved the decoration of this place.
I loved the cute tables and chairs, I loved the cute table clothe, and I loved the cute teapots, and plates that served our food.
The cream tea choice came with scones, devon cream, and fresh fruits.
Omgosh, the scone took my breath away.
It was melted in my mouth.
I was expecting something super sweet, but nope, it was just perfect.
Not too sweet, but not too bland.
And the cream and jam were all so good that I kept trying to add both on the scone for every bite.
When the tea came out, we had the chance to add our own sugar and cream, so I loved that.
I had control over how much diabetes I wanted to give myself.
jk.
